output: Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Madam Vice-President, the Commission gives the impression of acting like a distracted student who is trying to make up for lost time before handing in his paper.
Certainly, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be considered as a step towards taking social issues into account by the Commission.

The President of the Commission has not taken the measure of the warning given by the citizens in France, the Netherlands and Ireland, and which would unfortunately have been identical elsewhere in the event of a popular vote.
These elections are a wake-up call.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a social project and not just to adopt even more technical directives.
Regulation relating to the internal market is certainly necessary, but it is not, and far from being, the essential.
The 2009 program, like the previous ones, will miss the point.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to add to or even simplify the legislation.
They expect the Commission to be up to the task assigned to it by the Treaties, the locomotive, the idea box of the Union.
It is not enough for its president to be wise and silent, standing at attention behind the president of the council.
We are expecting the Commission to act as a key player in the reflection on the nature of the societal project that we need.
But what is the social project in this program?
The 2009 program does not contain any serious errors, but it is not the program that our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new college to take its responsibilities.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the people than the current one.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, a question for the Council.

What has become of the high-level conference on Georgia that was proposed by the French Presidency? And how does the current Presidency of the Union intend to defend Georgia's territorial integrity when one country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia?
It's a shame that Mr. Barroso is not here because in his speech, he was not convincing, perhaps because he himself is not convinced by the proposals he made to us.
I think the financial and economic situation is much more serious than he described it to us.
Today, I still believe that those who follow the Internet can see very well that the stock markets continue to collapse despite the interventions.

So, for me, it's really the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that led to bankruptcy, that led to a land being totally exploited and suffocated by greenhouse gas emissions, that led to underdevelopment in the South and that led to underdevelopment in our cities.
I thank Madam President, Madam Commissioner. The current financial crisis clearly shows that when the problem is global, global action is needed.
And this is especially true in the field of agriculture or food.
This is why we created, among other things, the World Trade Organization, which we agree on, and which tries to have global rules.

It turns out that it doesn't work quite as we would like, because we are faced with a problem which is the following: we have to reconcile two things, the necessary free trade on which everyone agrees, but also the necessary protections.
And the protection of national economies or agriculture does not mean protectionism.
The path we have taken for 60 years, since the GATT, is an unbalanced path that goes from the reduction of customs duties with the objective of their abolition.
It turns out that technically, the reduction of customs duties
It is difficult. Proof: a whole series of mathematical formulas, the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn’t really work because a product is not unitary.
It is made up of many elements with rules of very different origins, and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as one might think.
We are therefore in a technical deadlock and we are trying politically, through negotiations, to get out of this deadlock.

However, it turns out that technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology, the technology of deductible customs duties, deductible by the exporter on the economy of the importing State.
Concretely, this deductible customs duty is transformed into a customs credit equal to the amount of the customs duty that the exporter has borne in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characteristics: it is refundable, negotiable and redeemable.
It is reimbursed at the time when the exporter goes to buy from the importer, he can deduct the customs duty that he has borne.
It is negotiable because if the exporting company that has paid the customs duties has nothing to buy from the importer, it negotiates its customs credit on the stock market or in a bank.
And it is beneficial if we want to help developing countries, the importer can offer a customs credit amount greater than the customs duty amount.
Well, with this technique, we create an international trade currency whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer 13 billion euros in international currency in the commercial field.

Thank you, Mr. President. The Russo-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis have been an opportunity for the European Union to assert itself on the world stage as a full-fledged and first-rate political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has managed to unite and find coordinated, effective and rapid responses.
In the face of crises, Europe proves that it exists and it demonstrates its added value.
In terms of immigration, for example, every man for himself was no longer in fashion.
The adoption by the European Council of the Pact on Migration and Asylum, initiated by the French Presidency, is a significant step forward.
In the fight against climate change, Europe must set itself concrete objectives and show the way to its global partners.

You have already expressed yourself on this subject, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish that this agreement be as balanced as possible, since it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which is currently very unstable.
but also to ask ourselves the question of the type of development that we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges ahead, the European Union needs the Treaty of Lisbon more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must propose a solution to us at the December European Council. We are many to ask for it.
Over the past few weeks, we have proudly observed a strong political Europe, united in adversity, determined with its partners, listened to on the international scene.
We wish that this new European mindset becomes the norm and that it endures.
The Lisbon Treaty is the best solution we had to achieve this. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President. Mr. Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan. And of course, I pay tribute to him for having acted quickly and having been able to stop this war.
But this war is a bit of our failure. We have shown ourselves to be timid for 14 years. We have silently watched the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

This war has certainly awakened Europe by placing it in front of its responsibilities. But the fire continues to smolder in the Caucasus, and we must do everything to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all of Europe.
I am also aware of the divisions, Mr. Minister, among European countries regarding Georgia's entry into NATO. And personally, I am against it.
And I will make you a proposal. I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these countries of the Caucasus.
And only the status of neutrality can appease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this sub-region from new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.
Commissioner, Minister, over the last three days, the European Development Days were held, where the food crisis that is severely affecting the poorest countries was widely discussed.
All the interventions stressed the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally using their land and natural resources.

In passing, the lyrical flights of those who yesterday and still today call for a reduction in state intervention and public spending, for liberalization in all directions, for privatization, for the relegation of agriculture as a mere commodity,

This almost prehistoric activity, this about-face in favor of massive public investment in agricultural production and food sovereignty, all this has something both ridiculous and scandalous about it.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Unfortunately, I do not feel that this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the food riots and the disastrous market disorders, takes into account the situation of the peasantries of the South and draws all the consequences of the serious risks that we know today, ecological, social, economic and financial.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between the agriculture of the North and the South is so little addressed, both in the Commission's proposals and in the Parliament's report. Thank you, Madam. And the questioning of the promised billion euros shows how long the road still is.
Mr. President, the report that we will vote on tomorrow marks the culmination of a year of work and negotiations dedicated to the future of the Common Agricultural Policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was on November 20 last that Mrs. Fischer-Bowl came to make her proposals to us on the health bill.
After the report of the Lutze-Göbel tables, here comes the report of Capula-Santo on the proposal of the Commission.
We must congratulate our two colleagues for their excellent work.
The European Parliament's Agriculture Committee has remained firm in the face of the Commission's initial proposals, which we found to be far too liberal.
I will remain vigilant regarding the dairy sector and, in particular, the measures preceding the abolition of quotas.

I am particularly thinking of mountain milk producers who should not be the poor relations of this reform, and we must ensure that they are not left behind, as they will need more support than others.
I don’t want to play Cassandra, but how can we imagine the French dairy industry grouped together in the same regions?

It is therefore with benevolence that I welcome the proposal to set up a milk fund and that which consists of evaluating from 2010 the increase in milk quotas according to the evolution of the market.

The calculation of the progressive modulation made by the Agriculture Commission seems fair to me. It would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas and to preserve biodiversity in a sustainable way.
I also congratulate the clarification of eco-conditionality, the implementation of which was until now a real headache for farmers.

I also wish that we keep the amount of the tobacco fund, which allows us to keep our small farms in Europe, as well as a significant workforce in a region where nothing else can be exploited and which allows us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Mr. Minister, we have greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have shown a lot of patience and determination, and you have not spared your time, far from it.
It was a real pleasure to work alongside you.
You would have been very effective with us.
I know we can count on you.
Mr. President, first of all, thank you for the work done and the conclusions and orientations proposed by the health check of the CAP, from the report of Mr. Caboulo Santos.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond to simple market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also, and too often, on territories and employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a serious blow to our agriculture.
The decoupling, for example, constitutes a real difficulty for certain livestock farming areas, dairy and sheep, and I am pleased to have heard Mrs. Fischer-Boll earlier intervene on this issue.
Moreover, it is clear that strictly maintaining historical references would put a huge brake on any possibility of reform.
However, I still believe that the issue of the second pillar of the CAP is an essential one because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in the rural world.
And so we must think about this second leg issue without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Mr. Minister Jouyet is going to leave us, I think that this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most diligent ministers we have ever known.
Lucette, good luck!

Yes, Madam President, I voted for the Perich report on the integration of the OCM 20 into the old Munich. I must say, with a heavy heart, that I consider this single OCM to be neither a simplification nor an increase in transparency.
It will make life more complicated for winegrowers and the entire wine industry.
Last night, the Commissioner tried to reassure us.
I hope that the Commission will keep its word and that the profession will continue to be adequately represented on the advisory committees, as has been the case since the first OCM 20. Thank you.
Monsieur
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act project that was presented to us by the Commission in June.

Indeed, since the 2000s, initiatives have been taken in the direction of SMEs, and I am thinking in particular of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Vlasto on the SME charter. Initiatives that have been appreciated but judged insufficient because they too often remained in the state of wishes.
Today, we must go further.
The serious economic crisis that our countries are going through, and whose consequences are particularly worrying for SMEs, invites us to do so if we needed to.
In this regard, the Small Business Act is part of a new, resolutely voluntarist approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine the report of Mrs. Herzog on the communication of the Commission, but today, through the submission of this oral question, we wanted to challenge the Council.

Mr. Minister, we have taken note with interest of the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council, and we would like to know if the European Council of the 11th and 12th of December will
will relay its conclusions and will give a strong impetus so that the main guiding principle "Think Small First" is quickly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We wish that the Council commits to the principle of the action plan that is attached, with concrete measures.
In this regard, and in the short time I have, I will emphasize three directions in which we need compelling impulses.
The impact studies, which should be systematic, and the regular monitoring, with the control of the European Parliament, of the state of application of the Small Business Act in the Member States.
Access to the public market
The code of conduct has no binding force. We must, together, be more imaginative, more inventive, and propose concrete, adapted measures that truly open up PME markets.
Finally, access to financing, more essential than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are good, Mr. Minister. They must also integrate support for the offer.
There is an emergency.
Thank you for assuring us of the Council's will.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, since they employ more than 70% of the European Union's workforce and represent 99% of European companies.

But as has already been said, these millions of small and medium-sized businesses are now worried and threatened by the financial crisis, because it is degrading the purchasing power and confidence of households, impacting order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is consequently necessary to ensure that their activities are supported by ensuring that banks guarantee effective access to the financing necessary for the continuity of their operations.
This is the whole point of the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council of December 1st, which Mr. the Minister spoke about, and of the recovery plan approved by the European Ministers of Finance.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority for the Union is essential, and I wanted to commend the action plan in favor of the Small Business Act for Europe.
It indeed translated the will to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle, to give priority to the small first, that is to say to European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner said, and as we all say, the Council must truly commit, with the other institutions,
European, for this principle to now be effective, we must go beyond the declaration, we must move on to implementation in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a real response to the urgency of the situation.
And I wanted, Mr. Minister, to praise the commitment of the French Presidency of the Union, which has made it possible to quickly translate intentions into action.

Mr. President, Madam President in office, Mr. Commissioner, I give my full support to the rapporteur who is defending the position that was ours in first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
It was urgent to bring our legislation on working time into line with the case law of the Court of Justice. This has been done.
The Cercas report provides balanced and protective answers for employees.
All the time spent on standby is counted as working time.
Compensatory rest occurs immediately after the period of service.
It is a matter of common sense to ensure decent working conditions, especially for medical professions.
But the reform of the working time directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social law by abolishing the individual opt-out.
The Cercas report seizes this opportunity and proposes a gradual elimination of any possibility of derogation from the maximum legal working time.
We must face reality.
It is a joke to say that the employee is in a situation of equality with his employer and can refuse what is proposed to him.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly show the governments of the Member States that the text they want to impose on us is unacceptable.

And in the concert of praise that will certainly lull the ears of the French government from tomorrow, it seems necessary to us to be interested above all in the employees who will be called upon to work more and more, without really having a choice, and this like all those to whom we will ask tomorrow to work on Sunday in France.
It is indeed clearly to open this possibility that the French government has changed its position on individual opt-out at the Council.

My dear colleagues, let us listen to the workers and try to respond to their call. If we do not want the negative votes of the French, Dutch and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, calling into question a European Union that would give them the feeling of not dealing with their daily problems. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. It was a very beautiful French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices to disagree with this.
The 27 have overcome their differences to reach a series of decisions that have been exemplary.
On the energy-climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this, this first step is huge.
It now has the means to assume its environmental responsibility without, however, sacrificing its economy.
It can now take the lead in this area to guide other continents towards sustainable development.
Moreover, Ireland is proposing a scenario to get out of its isolation.
Our Irish friends will vote again on the Lisbon Treaty, with all the cards in hand, since practically all the other members will have definitively voted.
The current crises show us that the Union needs better institutional tools more than ever to be effective.
The European Council has adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the most severely affected industrial sectors.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates and I totally share his point of view.
Let us hope that the ministers of economy and finance will reach an agreement in March, which seemed impossible to the heads of state and government last weekend.
The trials that Europeans are facing give the Union the opportunity to reveal itself to them as more united, more reactive, more concerned with protecting them.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for having breathed new life into this dynamic.
We wish, like Nicolas Sarkozy, not to see again so soon the councils of yesterday that ended at 4 am to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the last six months, Europe has indeed changed its mindset, its scope, and its credibility.
We must thank the French Presidency for this. We are well aware that it is not entirely foreign to it. Thank you, Mr. President.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
What we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.

But we are asking the Security Council to take a position. We are asking the authorities to take a position, that the European Union take a position. And we, in Parliament, we discuss and we do not want to take a position.

I think that, given the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is extremely important that this Parliament speaks out and says exactly what it wants to stop the massacres that are taking place in the Middle East at the moment.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and the clarity to vote on a resolution after our debate.
This is why our group is asking to revise the decision of the Conference of Presidents and to end the debate that we must have.
...to have a resolution on the situation in Gaza, which will demonstrate the clear and firm position of this Parliament, of a majority, to stop the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution. We must be aware that we have a political responsibility in the face of what is happening. And this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion. It must be a resolution that clearly states what we want and what we condemn.
Please, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, more than ever, the draft directive that the Parliament is about to vote on arouses in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr. Klins, has been doing long-term work for years and has negotiated with talent, notably during the trilogue.

It is also true that the directive has a number of significant advances in the direction of better functioning of the internal market, collective management of financial assets and is welcomed as such by the European investment fund industry.

It remains that the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament were never entirely free, since the outcome was known in advance. For some actors, it was necessary at all costs to introduce the European passport for management companies.
In principle, there is nothing to say against it, the passport is perfectly defensible. However, it must be ensured that the introduction of the passport for management companies
It is accompanied by the necessary guarantees, in particular with regard to the supervision of funds, since it leads to a separation of functions beyond borders.
However, I regret to note that the system put in place is not only complex, but also subject to divergent interpretations.
They will soon run into practical difficulties that will harm European industry, especially in terms of exports, particularly exports to third countries.
I have taken note of my minority position, but I do not feel uncomfortable.
Under normal circumstances, I would have been tempted to say that only practice will allow us to draw definitive conclusions on the matter and therefore to determine
Who is right between those who trust in the ability of market players to adapt and those who take a more cautious approach?
It is not excluded that the subject is at the end, but on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
However, the very recent news, notably the Madoff scandal and its implications on the industry of collective management of financial assets, is not reassuring.
Skepticism is followed by my concern.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, we are already seeing this.
It is possible that fundamental rethinking is necessary in this context of crisis.

That in these contexts of deep crisis, we would make choices that dilute the responsibilities of the actors or that presuppose perfect cooperation between control authorities can really be seen as an incongruity.
I'm telling you what I think, this directive is also from a bygone era, before the crisis.
It is marked by a certain carelessness.
Indeed, the financial system will go through a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence. Entire parts of its architecture will have to be rethought.

Let us not forget the primary function of the OPCM and the protection of the investor through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting on this text as it is, without really knowing where we are going, we are acting as if nothing had happened.
This autism does not bode well, that is why I will abstain, even if I have signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances, the improvements made seem to me to be of little weight in the face of the questions of principle that I have just explained.

Mr. President, although the regulation on the animal report has been in force since January 2007, it seems that the Member States are not systematically complying by providing, as requested, annual reports.
A global analysis is therefore still random, since many elements are missing regarding the means implemented to carry out inspections.
As a member of an animal protection association and a member of the intergroup for the defense of animals, this subject is of particular concern to me.
The associations have been fighting desperately for decades to finally establish guidelines in this area in 2007, where we see that the Member States are showing some laxity.
I would even dare to say that there is a certain bad faith, because, after all, we know that the implementation of controls and inspections is absolutely not insurmountable.
We know the slaughterhouses, we know the breeding grounds, we know the routes for transporting livestock, so what is the problem?

I believe that it is important in our time, when public opinion is increasingly, and rightly, sensitive to animal welfare, whether in terms of breeding, slaughtering or transport conditions, that States respect these feelings.

And since I have the floor, I would like to add that, regarding transport, it would be essential to consider and take into account, independently of the transport times, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a transport of several hours carried out in the Netherlands in the spring has nothing comparable to the same transport time in the summer in a country such as Greece.
Shouldn’t we impose nighttime transportation in these last cases?
I thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Mr. President, I am pleased that it is a Briton, our colleague Parrish, who has submitted this text, as if the Roman soldiers 2000 years ago had done well to go to Great Britain and bring amphorae of olive oil and wine.
But then we would have to draw conclusions.

It is not very reasonable symbolically to put the food agency in Helsinki, and it is not reasonable that the European Commission does not backtrack on the following points. First, to restore aid for almond growers, then to stop the...

The attacks on olive trees, especially in Andalusia and throughout Europe, the attacks on bluefin tuna fishermen in the Mediterranean, and the attacks on European vineyards with the uprooting of vines.
I suggest to our Commissioner, our President, Mr. Barroso, to organize a big banquet in Portugal with sheep cheese and wine from the Douro region.
Thank you, Mr. President. We have indeed all campaigned for the closure of Guantanamo, and we have all welcomed the decision of President Obama to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of welcoming the detainees from Guantanamo should not be posed to us.
As Europeans, faithful to our values of defending the rights of the individual, we must take our responsibilities, for it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we have been able to read, and here I am addressing the Council, we have been able to read in the press that some Member States were not very keen on this reception.
So, I would really like to make an appeal to the Council, and in particular to the reluctant Member States, to accept to receive these detainees on their territory.
And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst would be if the goodwill generated by the closure of Guantanamo were to fade because we had not responded when Europe was called upon.

This is important because the European animal feed sector is one of the most important sectors in agriculture, both in terms of production, as it represents half of the agricultural production in the European Union (120 million tonnes), and in terms of turnover, around 50 billion euros.
The European Union has 5 million livestock farmers and 60 million households with pets.
In the past, the European Union has had to manage a number of health crises, which is why today we must be more vigilant about transparency to meet the expectations of farmers but also consumers.

The provisions in this report have the advantage of representing a minimal cost for industries and a great benefit for consumers who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they buy.
The adoption of this report will help limit risks by ensuring better product quality, better control, better traceability, and better information for the breeder and, ultimately, the consumer.
Today, with the increase in international trade, it is more than imperative to strengthen all prevention measures so that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not happen again.

This report manages to reconcile the right to information, while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must be mandatory on labels, and the right to intellectual property, which is so important to preserve the competitiveness of our industries.

I think that manufacturers should be required to immediately notify the use of any new raw materials used in the composition of animal feed in order to ensure transparency and facilitate the control carried out by the competent authorities.
The fact of including an emergency procedure that allows a new dangerous substance to be introduced into the list of prohibited substances seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Likewise, giving the breeder the possibility to question the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt about an unfair claim allows for better verification of the systems, thus protecting the client while preserving the fairness of commercial transactions.

I would therefore like to give my full support to this excellent report, as experience shows that regulation on the labeling of animal feed, I conclude, Mr. President, favoring quality, transparency, traceability and control is the best guarantee to prevent new food crises in Europe.

Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, and even less its High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Javier Solana, former Secretary General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
They are even more likely to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they are doing today for Kosovo, Lebanon or Afghanistan.
The Americans and the Israelis bomb, the Europeans finance the reconstruction.
What is the division of tasks between allies?
But it should be the rioters who pay!
Egypt is at the center of peace talks that aim for a prolonged ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be met is formidable in that the new Israeli government, under the pressure of the third man, Lieberman, head of an extreme right that is democratically accepted there, risks seeing its task singularly complicated in this negotiation.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty: Mahmoud Abbas' Palestinian Authority has become a kind of international protectorate in the West Bank, whose legitimacy has greatly diminished among the population.
Last element to take into account, the expansion of Israeli colonies, which has never stopped since 1967, makes the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly delicate.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli camp, but do the hawks in both camps accept this truce of God that both parties are calling for without giving themselves the means?
Allow me to add a reflection on the reintegration of France into the integrated military structure of NATO, which will be debated with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will entail severe obligations for France.
Indeed, we are reintegrating NATO while the Cold War has been over since 1990.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of free nations.
Should we strengthen the logic of the blocks at a time when multipolarization and the rise of emerging countries, including in the military field, are taking place?
Moreover, France's adherence to the integrated structure will oblige it to reinforce its contingent in Afghanistan, even though it already has 3,300 men on the ground.
With what budget will it be financed, when its defense budget will fall below 2% of GDP and more than 30 regiments will be eliminated?
Paradoxically, we are going to increase our budgetary participation to join NATO and reduce our military presence in Africa at the same time.
The European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
It was enough to read the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced.
Whether it is in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European way is a dead end that will only lead to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of sovereignty and national independence, which is based in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent force.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs for this remarkable synthesis they have produced of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Mr. High Representative, you know better than anyone else, Europe is expected today on the world stage to take the place that its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanist values assign to it.

It must be acknowledged that despite the regularly expressed will of more than two-thirds of our European fellow citizens, as you have said, certain progress has been made, I grant you, over the past ten years, but it must also be acknowledged that this Europe still does not exist.
If a recent illustration were needed, its erasure in the solution of the new drama in the Middle East would be there to demonstrate it.
There was, there is still a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role in both helping the population survive and rebuilding the country.
in the country and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had turned this territory into a launching base for rockets of all calibers.
Despite the good words given to Sharm el-Sheikh and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

I am renewing here a question already asked during the Lebanese crisis. When can we, Mr. High Representative, hope for the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean as we had one in the face of piracy?
We have the means.
Will we one day honor the will?
Well, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, my dear colleagues, the decision of the Parliament to accept the urgency requested by the Council for the...
The handling of this case was unanimous, both at the Fisheries Commission last week and this morning here in plenary.
We are indeed all aware of the need for the European Union to honor the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the competent international commission, the CICDA.
It is a matter of concretely implementing the recommendations adopted by this organization in order to support the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean.
in the eastern Atlantic and in the Mediterranean and to face the serious dangers that result from this for the future of the species and therefore that of fishing itself.
Two of our colleagues from the Fisheries Commission, Mrs. Fraga and Mr. Romeva i Rueda, were present in Marrakech and will speak about it during this debate.
I would like to remind you of the importance that our Commission attaches to this file, which involves the main dimensions of the Common Fisheries Policy, namely the management of

the resource, the management of the fleet, the respect of international, regional and bilateral agreements, the technical measures and above all, and above all, the control, I will come back to that later.
This case is therefore characteristic, and consequently serves as a test in our eyes of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, it was obviously out of the question that the implementation of the new recovery plan should take place without consulting the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has finally chosen the only legally and politically acceptable path for the implementation of the
the recommendation of the CJEU, namely that of a proposal for a regulation in good and due form on the basis of Article 37 of the Treaty.

The transposition of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union into regional fishing organizations is not, in fact, a trivial operation, and we insist that it always be carried out under the democratic control of our institution.
On the substance, I am pleased with the various measures proposed, which, although constraining for our operators, are commensurate with the stakes. And I emphasize that the most important
The important measures are certainly those that concern and will concern control, since it is true that without control, no reconstruction plan can be effective.
I therefore thank you, Mr. Commissioner, for this proposal. I invite you to show as much determination as...
the determination in the concrete implementation of the plan, once it has been approved by the Council, that you have shown in reaching a satisfactory agreement at the CICA level.
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet undertaken to concretely define territorial cohesion.
The French presidency has tried to do so, and I would like to commend this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable as of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and that its contours be specified as soon as possible.

I wish, like the excellent report of Mr. Van Nistelrooy, that territorial cohesion becomes the legal basis guaranteeing the harmonious development of all the territories of the Union and allowing the best to be made of the characteristics specific to each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
The territorial cohesion is not intended to target exclusively the regions suffering from permanent disabilities.
It must, however, be committed to the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems relevant to me for taking into account the outermost regions in order to ensure them sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I would like to thank the rapporteur for having taken up in his compromise amendments my requests relating to the specific challenges faced by the outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, an essential element of territorial cohesion.
Reading the recent communication from the Commission entitled "The RUP, an asset for Europe", it seems to me that it wants to apply to the outermost regions the whole of the...
recommendations for improving cohesion governance, thus making the RUP the first illustration, albeit a little early, of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the States General of the Overseas, which will soon begin in France, will proceed in the same way and will largely integrate the major territorial impact of European policies in favor of the RUP, whose added value is undeniable.
able and uncontested.
We have fun reading the conclusions of the presidency of the last Council.
It looks like the victory communiqué of all the armies in retreat.
They are laughable, even in the repeated assertion that, with the crisis ending, the EU will build a stronger economy for the future, or in the reaffirmation of a Lisbon strategy in full disarray.
Thus, as they lock themselves in their ivory tower, Eurocrats, Europhiles and Europhobes of all kinds end up not taking the measure of things.
Everyone knows that the eurozone was the first to enter recession and had the lowest rate in the world for eight years.
But it is also the one that faces the greatest difficulties in terms of its industrial competitiveness and employment situation.
Above all, it is the one that, through the general disarmament of the natural defenses taken away from nations, is the least armed to react.
In reality, the only merit of this crisis will be to awaken the people lulled by the ease of financial anticipation and by anti-national propaganda.
Only the States will have the necessary legitimate instruments for any large-scale action, and they will have to shake off the shackles of the EU and the Euro.

For the French, in any case, it is becoming increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French policy, no French policy without national and popular sovereignty. Thank you, Mr. President.

Thank you, Madam President. I believe that the question of the distribution of foodstuffs to the benefit of the most disadvantaged is indeed timely. But I believe that, in essence, the Commission's proposal does not correspond to the problem.

The question of co-financing is puzzling me, and I am thinking that it is rather the question of liberalism that has presided over the evaluations of the CAP in recent years that is to be called into question.
Riots against hunger, the brutal variations in the price of foodstuffs are permanent indicators of the limits of the liberalization of agricultural markets.
This liberalization has always been done at the expense of vulnerable populations, at the expense of vulnerable producers and vulnerable territories.

I therefore plead for politics to reclaim its rights, to take the lead, both at the European and global levels, and for the strategic field of agriculture and food for humans, both quantitatively and qualitatively, not to be subject to the strict laws of the market.
Certainly, there is urgency, and the Sikerski report responds to this urgency, and I am pleased about that. But I wish that, in the case of the reflection that is opening up on the...
As regards the future of the CAP, it should be recalled that the priority objective is indeed to structurally combat hunger and poverty, which we know in all Member States and in the world.
Rural areas are available to meet food needs through sufficient and quality production. However, they must be given the financial and human means to ensure this heavy responsibility.
Thank you, Mr. President. In this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continue to show its solidarity towards developing countries.
Let us recall that in 2007, the European Community and the Member States together contributed 60% of the total aid for development, making the European Union the world's leading donor.
The European Development Funds help fight poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that for the ACP countries, a budget of 23 billion euros has been allocated for the 2008-2013 period, within the framework of the 10th FED, which represents practically double the amount provided for the 9th FED.
The Court of Auditors concluded in its report that the accounts of the 7th, 8th and 9th FEDs are generally faithful, legal and regular.
We can only be pleased with the record levels of contract execution and payments for the implementation of the FEDs.
However, I also note that progress must be made to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as there is still a significant level of error affecting certain transactions.
Likewise, there is a risk that is too often high in terms of budgetary support, and it is necessary, in my opinion, to better assess these risks.
On this subject, I share the idea that budgetary support should only be granted if the beneficiary country has the capacity to manage the funds in a transparent, responsible and effective manner.

Among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the FED into the general budget of the community, as this would strengthen the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

To conclude, Mr. President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the members of the Commission who have done excellent work on the ground. And I regret, of course, the absence of the Council and in particular the Czech Presidency.
Madam President, Parliament and its rapporteur were forced to refuse a bad compromise. They were right to do so.
Our delegation remained faithful to the position adopted very widely in plenary and which demanded the suppression in the long term of any derogation from the legal duration of work.
But the truth is that Parliament was the only one who wanted to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had decided, beyond party lines, to put an end to this archaic system called the opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a genuine compromise text that the Council of Ministers superbly ignored, just like the Commission, by the way.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with the position of those who are fiercely opposed to any progress in workers' rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have achieved your goals.
The Court of Justice requires you to consider all the time spent on guard duty as working time, so you have not lost anything on that side.
The opt-out you want still exists in practice, so the status quo has prevailed.
More than ever, the deputies elected in June will have to fight for a harmonization of social standards.
Mr.

Mr. President, this is certainly not in the name of the Libé Commission, it is presumably in the name of my group. I would like to take this brief minute to give my extraordinarily positive appreciation of the report of Mrs. Paganov.
Congratulations, Madam, on your report.

I believe that in writing this report, you have drawn up an extraordinarily precise statement of work for elements that should be prominently featured, Mr. Commissioner, in the Stockholm program, which I know the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to everything that has been said regarding the importance of training magistrates, the importance of evaluation, to emphasize two fundamental elements in terms of mutual trust, which are the basis of what could be tomorrow's mutual recognition.
1. The independence of the judiciary.
At the moment, there are a number of countries in the Union where the independence of the judiciary from political power or from other powers is not established.
This is a scandal and this scandal must stop.
2. Procedural safeguards

As long as we are not sure that in a certain number of countries, people who are suspected or accused of having committed certain types of offenses benefit from procedural guarantees similar to those that exist in other countries, it is difficult to have the principle of mutual recognition widely accepted.
It is a fundamental element and I wanted to introduce it in this debate.
Congratulations, Mrs. Pagan.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent about the situation in Madagascar. And we will not be alone in condemning this situation.

The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organization of La Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union speaking on behalf of the Commission, the

The USA, a large number of countries, including mine and Norway, to name a country on the European continent, have condemned the coup d'état, because we must call a spade a spade, that took place in Madagascar.
So we cannot remain silent and we are demanding a return to constitutional legality.
We never ask for anything other than a return to square one, with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people through a consultation in the form of a presidential election or referendum.
It is up to the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
So what we are asking for with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly indicate to those who have taken power in a completely non-democratic way

democratic and in the form of a coup d'état, however disguised, to return to the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantors of the future development of this large island in the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his answers, and for the attention he continues to pay to all these disasters.
We worked a lot together when President Barroso asked us to prepare a report, which he even quoted, on the creation of a European civil protection force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
When I reread it and see all the disasters that have occurred, I tell myself that it is still relevant.
Mrs. Zavella, obviously, there is not only Greece.
All countries are affected. And I would add that there are not only natural disasters, there are also human disasters caused by humans.
I am thinking of maritime disasters, the Erika and many others, industrial accidents of the Chernobyl type.
There are other natural disasters besides fires.
I am thinking about the tsunami.
We can fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean one day, as there was one at the beginning of the 20th century that totally destroyed the city of Messina.
Frankly, Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues, the tools we are using are not up to the task of these disasters that will multiply due to the dual effects of climate change and transportation.
And that is why I think we need to be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all the teams of the General Directorate who make the civil protection mechanism work.
I think we need to go further.
Created with the Member States that wish to do so, we can imagine enhanced cooperation.
If we are not 27 to form this civil protection force, let's start with 12 or 15.
And you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I list the disasters, I can say that everyone is concerned. The floods that hit Germany in 2002, and even the major pandemics, and also terrorism.
So, Mr. Commissioner, that is why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States to go further.
And our Parliament, the Environment Commission, the Defense and Security Commission will support you in these initiatives.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, Members of Parliament, this summer, the Mediterranean forest was once again the prey of flames, in Marseille, in southern Corsica, but also in Italy, in Spain, and on a larger scale in Greece.
More than 400,000 hectares of forest and fields have gone up in smoke, causing considerable material damage, irreparable damage to biodiversity, as well as dramatic loss of human life.
Stunned by this repeated balance sheet, year after year, and aware of the multiplier effect of global warming on fires,
I call for a European awareness for better coordination of efforts and a pooling of anti-firefighting resources.
I wish for the realization of a vast project of Euro-Mediterranean cooperation to fight forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I commend the existing initiatives, and in particular the European Forest Fire Information System, a pilot project.
I nevertheless demand a reform of the European Union Solidarity Fund so that it becomes an effective tool for responding to crises and strengthening the European force of prevention.
The protection and the Euroaid device, imagined by Michel Barnier since 2006, to intervene on the territory of the 27 member countries as well as abroad.

I believe that one of the keys to the problem of forest fires lies in the exchange of knowledge and best practices in terms of prevention. And I would like to point out the pioneering role played by the forest firefighters in my own department.
And I can obviously make this example available to Europe, which can serve as a model.
Good morning, Madam President, good morning, Madam Commissioner. I will be brief.
I think there are two elements in this debate.
The current question is how to get out of this crisis.
And all the measures that are both helping farmers and intervention measures are necessary and absolutely necessary.
They must be supported and even consider that they be more important.
This is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Then, secondly, there is a structural question raised about the management of the milk market. And that is where there is a divergence with you, Madam Commissioner.
You are proposing to go in the direction of contractualization.

I am telling you in advance, the contractualization between industrialists and farmers, in the long run, with industries being competitive with each other, will lead to competition on a European scale.
We need public regulation to regulate a market.
There is no other alternative.
This is where the debate will have to take place after this crisis.
And I think that in this debate, we must respect all opinions and all options. And I fear that we went too fast at the time of the health check to resolve a question like quotas,

So far, I would say that all those who have intervened have made it possible to maintain dairy production in Europe, to ensure a highly developed dairy industry and at the same time to ensure a price for consumers that has so far been quite bearable. Thank you, Madam Commissioner.
Mr. President, a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I really have the impression that we can say that we are more European today than we were before.
I am delighted, truly, fully, serenely.
Unfortunately, unfortunately, we are still essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, but also on the goodwill of the Czech President.

We must send a clear signal of accountability to those who hold in their hands the future of this treaty, which is crucial for the Union, for our institutions and for the 500 million Europeans we represent.
We can no longer be held hostage by a few whose sole purpose is to thwart the general European interest.
It is legitimate that some wish not to go further in European integration, it is legitimate to express these reservations, but it is also legitimate to let those who wish to progress.
In general, the ratification processes of European treaties too often take on the appearance of sagas or Pyrrhic victories.
Are we doomed to constantly have to force the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms?
We must draw lessons from this chaotic ratification process and also, obviously, from this negotiation commitment in view of organizing a second referendum.

The referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to make a people vote again who had expressed themselves in a sovereign manner, and as if it were normal that an agreement on a treaty could be a bargaining chip.
The coherence and institutional balance of the European adventure are at stake.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimal requirement of loyalty and cohesion from the moment one chooses to have their country join the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to citizens by ratifying the treaty for the European elections of June 2009.
What do you think that today the citizen thinks of the Treaty of Lisbon and beyond our internal coherence and our legitimacy?
Thank you, Mr. President. My intervention concerns the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the world's workers earn less than $2 per day.
12.3 million people are still subjected to slavery and more than 200 million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of poor workers is increasing day by day. And the International Labour Organization counts 160,000 deaths each year due to lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are deprived of employment and social rights, who work in undignified conditions,
Of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide or victims of cancer or chronic diseases due to their working conditions.
It is time to move away from the religion of working more, from the race for profit, from short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the top of the Union's priorities for the next ten years.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To raise the stakes, Copenhagen must allow a global agreement, a single agreement, as our Environment Committee President, Jo Leinen, just pointed out. An alliance of all, industrialized countries, emerging countries, is necessary.

Today, with our debate, but also the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we are once again calling on the European Union to maintain its role as a leader in this necessary policy of fighting against climate change.
Let us remember that we must speak with one voice to maintain our credibility.
Yes, we must reach an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in the global average temperature to a level that does not exceed 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must sign an agreement in Copenhagen to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions of 30% by 2020 compared to 1990.
But that will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to significantly reduce their emissions, but also for developing countries to contribute to achieving the objectives.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, sustainable and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must thus enable developing countries to move towards low-carbon models.
Also, allow me to address two points that seem necessary to me for our future.
First of all, the implementation at the global level of funding to fight against global warming based on the taxation of financial transactions.

Then, I believe it is necessary to implement a fiscal adjustment at the borders of Europe that will take into account the importation of products manufactured without any concern for environmental protection. A fiscal adjustment linked to...

A contractualization and a transfer to the southern countries of the carbon tax thus collected at the borders of Europe and which would be used to finance investments in the equipment necessary for the fight against global warming.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to intervene in the same vein as my intervention yesterday on the preparation of the Copenhagen summit and following, moreover, the Ecofin meeting yesterday which was not crowned with success.
I asked you about the responsibility we have as an industrialized country to ensure that developing countries can follow us in our efforts to fight climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capacities, otherwise it would mean that we all start from the same point to end up with nothing.
To convince our development partners to join us, we will obviously have to address the issue of aid that must be granted to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
At the next European Council, the 27 will absolutely have to agree on how the European Union will help developing countries in the context of the important issue of climate change.
Yesterday, as I was saying, the Ecofin Council of Ministers of Finance did not manage to find a common position on this issue.
Yet we know that this question is absolutely central.
The European Commission had already made proposals. I absolutely want us to take the lead to bring our partners towards the global solidarity necessary to overcome this climate change problem.
I would like to thank the efforts of the Swedish presidency to reach an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the strong winds of pessimism blowing on these future negotiations.
As for me, I think that it is not realistic to admit at this stage that the Copenhagen summit is dead or that it will not result in a conclusive agreement to be ratified by all parties.
Let us not give in to pessimism too quickly.
At this stage, I plead that we do not lower our ambitions, neither in terms of objectives nor in terms of deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a global, comprehensive, ambitious and binding political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible.
It is really too early to mention the deadline of COP 16 in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into real political will.
We must clarify our commitment in terms of financial aid and assistance to developing countries, particularly in terms of technology transfer.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment of the European Union is essential.

I also note on paper the recent but exemplary momentum given or to be given by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, Norway, in particular, who have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

While we can understand the flexibility demanded by the United States, which is only just beginning to take the climate issue into account, we must nevertheless achieve quantified, binding and ambitious commitments in the short, medium and long term from other major polluters such as the United States and China.
Otherwise, we are heading for climate, political and moral disasters.
Madam President, we all know, and we have all said, the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I clearly wish that the European Union is able to say no and refuse to sign a Rabat agreement.

The European populations that we represent here are waiting for an agreement, an agreement that will allow us to effectively fight against the whole range of climate changes that we observe every day around us.

They will not be satisfied with mere announcements, unquantified statements of intent, non-binding objectives on which it will be possible to wipe one's feet once the media spotlight has been turned off.

In Copenhagen, the States will have to commit. The European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent to plan precise, binding and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot alone bear the burden of the effort.

This is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to take on their share of the burden, we will have to draw all the consequences by instituting at our borders a tax protecting our industry from the competition of those who would decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans are asking more and more of our industrialists every day.
I have proof of this in the climate package that was signed under the French presidency.

I have proof of this in the national initiatives which, like the carbon tax, praised earlier by Mr. Parniaud, and I am pleased about this, these national initiatives are pushing for the establishment of an ecological tax system.

A sector like transport, which is among the major emitters of CO2, even if certain modes of transport like aviation emit less greenhouse gases, is contributing more and more to the fight against climate change.
However, this is a sector that has been very strongly affected by the backlash of the crisis.

If, as I wish, maritime and air transport are included in the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us ensure that what is demanded of European industries is also demanded of those in other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, the world's public opinion will have its eyes riveted on its leading class. Please finish. Do not disappoint us. Thank you.
Madam President, my dear colleagues, the Copenhagen summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must reach decisions that are even more binding than those made in Kyoto.
We too must call on our leaders to create an international organization like the WTO to regulate climate change and environmental issues, to create a fund
Adaptation to climate change, in addition, of course, to public aid for development, to create a carbon tax on maritime and air transport, as we must also do on financial transactions.
We clearly see the pressing need for global environmental regulation, as well as for financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this march of history through the environment.
Let us do it, in the image of our highest human aspirations, without which we will appear to be responsible without any grasp of reality. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, my dear colleagues. Less than two weeks before the Copenhagen Conference, concerns are growing about the success of the climate change negotiations.
Some, moreover, are already saying that it will be a failure.
Major world powers, including Russia, still need to demonstrate the full ambition that the climate emergency requires.

By adopting the resolution proposal tomorrow on the strategy of the European Union before the Copenhagen Conference, we, European parliamentarians, must show that our determination is first and foremost total and that the conference must lead to an agreement that is certainly precise but above all binding.
Moreover, the binding nature of this agreement, once found, should not be able to be called into question.

We cannot indefinitely postpone decision-making to tomorrow, otherwise it will be too late. Hence the necessary creation of a World Environment Organization, which appears today not only necessary but also urgent, since it will be led under the aegis of the UN to monitor the application of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
We must be able to expect great things from this world, starting from Copenhagen, more lucidity and responsibility.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to support the joint initiative of the British socialist government and the French government to send back to their country Afghans in an illegal situation.
Indeed, contrary to what some people have said, these people had their request for political asylum rejected. This bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.
Migration pressure is a challenge that we must collectively rise to. This is the purpose of the Pact on Migration and Asylum, adopted a few months ago under the French presidency.
We must now go further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights funded by Frontex.

The decision of the 27 to ask the Commission to conduct a study on this subject is a first step. And Mr. Commissioner, I wish that the Commission would support this proposal, because the fight against illegal immigration is a demand of public opinion and particularly of the immigrant populations in a regular situation. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to return to a recent event, the Swiss vote on minarets.
Certainly, this vote took place in a non-EU member state, but it is clear that it touches on a question that is not foreign to us.
I would like to return to this event, as I also see it as an opportunity to talk about secularism, and we can never talk enough about secularism in this assembly.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism dominates the organization of our society. And I would like to say here some simple things.
First of all, the opposite of secularism is not religiosity, or even less spirituality.
The principle contrary to secularism is religious communitarianism, which dictates rules and laws superior to civil laws. Communitarianism that encloses individuals in infra-societal groups.
Our union, through its history, is multicultural and multi-ethnic.
It is, and it will be more and more so, and only secularism can allow individuals
Good day. Thank you. The CESAR program, which aims to modernize the management of air traffic in Europe, is a major project.

How will the Commission prepare the next phase of the redeployment of CESAR and, in particular, the financing of this program, which is essential for the environment as well as for our scientific and technical influence?
Will the Commission follow the recommendations of the 2007 report, according to which a high-level qualified personality should ensure the political follow-up of this program?
Indeed, it will require overcoming many legal, psychological and technical obstacles by unifying national air spaces and by having the controllers of different countries work together.
If Europe was not able to unify its sky, how could it build a strong political entity?
Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues. The importance of the issue of climate change is no longer in doubt.

Its short, medium and long term impacts are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESC in a certain national newspaper are making the headlines and certainly strengthening the positions of the skeptics.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to bear witness, to act and to correct the effects of this process that is climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this platform, not only thanks to the bold legislation that is ours in terms of limiting the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can really make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a bitter taste, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of limiting the increase in temperature to 2 degrees, even for a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just passed a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 39% by 2020, in line with its commitments.
Many others have also shown great ambition regarding the objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
I am thinking of Japan and Norway.
Moreover, it is also important to highlight this very positive point which was the consensus reached regarding the urgency of a mechanism to reduce emissions due to deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was obtained on the implementation of the REDD+ mechanism to reduce deforestation and thus allow the natural storage of CO2.
Far from a binding agreement, but clearly in line with a political agreement, the outcome of Copenhagen should lead us to question the reasons for such a disappointment.
I went to the Copenhagen conference, like many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help, to see a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe.
My disappointment was great because Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, and even more so when it comes to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must show itself to be stronger on the subject.
The meeting of our environment ministers in Seville did not lead to any results, and our leaders were uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Mrs. Hedegaard, with her proposals and commitments made before the Environment Commission, will be able to bring the ambitions of the European Union up to date.

Thank you, I give the floor to Mr. Baudis. Dear colleagues, to avoid caricatures, we have heard some this morning, I would like to recall some objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in the average income per inhabitant, and now the vast majority of Tunisians fall within the criteria defining membership in the middle class.

More than 90% of Tunisians benefit from social security. And more than a quarter of Tunisia's budget is devoted to education, so that this country is among the first to have achieved the Millennium Development Goals in primary education.
Finally, as Mr. Michel reminded us earlier, women's rights are recognized and guaranteed.
At the university, there are more female students than male students, 40% of professors are women, a quarter of the deputies or local elected officials or journalists are women.
Many countries would be envious of such results.
Thank you, Mr. President. The acts of fanatical criminals who killed Christians in Egypt cannot be attributed to an entire people and its government.
It would be unfair to hold Egypt and the Egyptians responsible for this abominable massacre, the perpetrators of which will be judged.
Let us not confuse the acts of a criminal with the policy of a country, let us not lump together fanatics and an entire population. Finally, by claiming to interpose
By taking sides between the Coptic Christians of Egypt and their Muslim compatriots, we are giving arguments to extremists who seek to portray Eastern Christians as agents of the West.
I heard you, excuse me, sorry, Madam President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening in Greece, in Portugal, tomorrow in Spain or in Ireland is scandalous.

These same Anglo-Saxon agencies, which were completely satisfied with the scoundrels and traders of toxic assets and saw nothing coming, are now extremely severe towards the states that rushed to the aid of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis caused by the irresponsibility of the markets and banks, and this massive aid, are directly responsible for the worsening of the public deficit and debt that these same markets are now claiming to sanction.
That's what the moralization of capitalism proclaimed by Mr. Sarkozy, the European Union and the G20 is all about.

All that bankers have learned from the crisis is that the taxpayer is an inexhaustible source of resources, profit and insurance. For the rumor goes that the extent of this panic comes from a large American bank that benefited from government aid.

an American and two hedge funds of the same nationality who want to make money both on the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and on the CDS market, these insurance policies on state loans which are themselves the subject of independent speculation.
It will not be enough to regulate the Hedge Funds, which you are afraid to do, or the markets for derivative instruments, as proposed by Mr. Barnier.
It is useless to create a European economic government.
The 27 are in the same boat anyway, and solidarity is not an option.
It is the free global circulation of capital that needs to be called into question, otherwise there will be no...
Thank you, Mr. President. Today, less than 15% of the stock of red tuna remains.
Given such figures, the solution seems obvious.
However, we must not forget the jobs affected by the decision that concerns us today.
It should be recalled that CITES is not intended to prohibit fishing, but only the international trade of this fish, 80% of which is exported to Japan.

By protecting the thon, we are indeed protecting a species that is dangerously overfished, but we are also encouraging the maintenance of a more balanced and sustainable fishing activity, a fishing activity that is intended for our domestic market and that creates jobs.

I am in favor of the idea of including the red snapper in Annex 1 of CITES. And while it seems to me that this decision will be positive, the Commission's help to allow a deep restructuring of the fishing sector
My question therefore concerns the modalities of this support.
France is asking for an 18-month extension, accompanied by financial measures for sailors and shipowners affected by a ban on trade.
What is the Commission's view on the subject?
Moreover, my concern, like that of many of my colleagues, is about fairness.
How can we ensure that ships flying the flag of countries such as Tunisia, Libya or others will apply the ban on international trade with the same rigor as we do?
What will be the new control and sanction measures?

The policy of sustainability of our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the necessary adjustments to the implementation of these measures.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has reported, this directive proposal is indeed a follow-up to a vote by Parliament, as you also recalled, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks backfiring on those we want to support.
By wanting to lighten the burden on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust that are essential to their management and the dynamism of their activity.
First of all, I think we need to be clear about the thresholds and what we call micro-entities.
It is a matter of SMEs with more than 10 employees, with more than 1 million euros in turnover.
Whatever the Member State, this represents a very large majority of companies.
Indeed, they may be local and have little presence on the community market, but the need to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them and these
They will have to deal with accounting rules every time they want to deal with a banking institution, with partners, or negotiate sometimes with tax, economic and social institutions.
