At that point, accounting rules will be imposed on them and they will have to pay perhaps more than for regular accounting to be able to meet criteria that they may not necessarily master.
I do not see any progress in the accounting obligation being imposed outside of any common framework in the European Union.
This is not simply a matter of competition. It is simply a matter of economic integration and community rights and equal treatment for all companies in the European Union.
That being said, the simplification of accounting obligations for SMEs is obviously a necessity.
Three initiatives, moreover, are going in this direction. Whether it is the proposal we are talking about today, whether it is the international IFRS framework,
whether it is the revision of the 4th and 7th accounting directives for which the European Commission should soon make proposals.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010, it would seem that they are being extended, but I do not believe that this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this.
to rush and do a half job. Because these three proposals, if they share the same objective, may not have the same articulation. And it seems to me that it would be better, Mr. Commissioner,

and clearer for businesses, to provide them with a single and comprehensive response that will allow them to reconcile the objective of simplification, the obligations desired by all, and the reality of the life of small businesses that need it.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of its directives and that this is detrimental to our reflection.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the issue of the exemption that divides today both the institutions and the European economic circles and to carry out an impact study.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner and my dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and other colleagues have indicated, on February 27 and 28, the violent storm Xynthia hit several French regions, causing 53 deaths and enormous material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity. It caused devastating floods on the French coast.
Once again, Europe is concerned.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have thus been declared in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes and the Pays de la Loire.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must show its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and a resolution, but also and above all through financial aid that we can support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore invite, and my colleague Christophe Béchut is associated with my approach, the European Commission to quickly release the Union Solidarity Fund to help the affected regions cope with the damage.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, and in particular our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I would also like to congratulate our rapporteur, Jörg Leichtfried, for his text and his spirit of cooperation in this case. I support in particular his proposals regarding the financing of aviation security, since we are talking here about aviation security and not aviation safety.

Our committee has been fighting for many years to have the principle accepted that the stricter measures in terms of safety must be the responsibility of the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, safety concerns not only travelers but all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to fight terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that air passengers alone should be responsible for financing security measures in airports and on board aircraft.
And all the more so since in transport modes such as rail and maritime, States finance, depending on the case, partially or totally the safety measures.
I therefore think that we must remain firm in the face of the Council and defend to the end Amendment 32 of the report adopted by our Transport Committee.
I had another point to address quickly.

While I support the progress made in terms of non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single and identical European system of security fees.
While requiring compliance with common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their current system of collecting fees.

And so, in states such as Spain, Italy or France, the fees are voted on by Parliament. And in this case, it must be the authority of appeal against the laws that must act as the independent supervisory authority.
And this is the subject of amendment 40, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The report I am presenting to Parliament aims to explain that in the fight against climate change, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
This week, nature reminds us that, in particular, volcanoes can have a major impact on human activities and on the climate.
However, this requires that men, and Europe in particular, take responsibility for combating what is called global warming.
My report attempts to show that agriculture can both continue to reduce its carbon emissions, reduce its fossil energy consumption, and above all, from another point of view,
...to actively participate in carbon sequestration to globally reduce carbon emissions and increase carbon sequestration.
This report attempts to show that in agriculture, we should move from a compartmentalized approach, which consists of opening a directive each time we have a problem,
on soils, on water, on pesticides, what else, and to try to address the agricultural issue with the ambition to deal with it in a global way, in a systemic way.
In this approach, we must be able to find ways to ensure that agriculture, as I was saying earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption, but also actively participates in carbon sequestration.
This is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, to biomass, and above all, what is close to my heart, related to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to fix organic carbon.

And I think that this path, which I am opening in this report, and which I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in plenary session in Brussels, this path must allow European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a...

ecological transition to this agriculture, which would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other agricultures, to ensure that it is capable of being economically efficient, ecologically efficient, and I also think, from that point on, socially efficient.

This report deals with a specific issue, the fight against global warming and agriculture, but it aims, I hope at least, to open up other perspectives to feed in particular the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I am addressing the Commission, I will address, and I often do so in the Agricultural Commission, I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I think we need to take a turn.
This 2013 pact must be ambitious.
It must be based on objectives that allow citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because the Europe of agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to sustainability.
This is, in any case, what I propose in this report, and this is what I hope the Parliament, in a large majority, will follow.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would first like to emphasize that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments, by closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner, was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over any other consideration. Under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines that are demanding the total and immediate reopening of airspace based on one or two test flights seems, at the very least, indecent.

I believe it was Mr. Hénin who spoke earlier about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with the train. I will take this opportunity to say how much I regret the air transport paralysis.
has been accentuated in certain countries such as France by the disorganization of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
To return to our subject, I would like to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the current disruptions.
This is a decision of common sense in a context already marked by the crisis, but this aid must be exceptional.

In this regard, I wish that among the criteria retained for the ROC III, the exemplary nature of the compensation provided by the companies to their clients who are victims of flight cancellations is included.
Indeed, it is not acceptable that some companies abuse the force majeure clause in order to escape their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261/2004.
The travelers are victims of the current situation and if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not have to bear the financial cost.
In addition, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And that is not normal either.

Companies, like travel agencies, have insurance that covers them in exceptional cases, like the one we have been experiencing for a few days, and so we must ensure that travelers are properly compensated for the cancelled flights.
Thank you, Mr. President. Chaos, disorder, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disaster, the words are not lacking in the press to evoke the closure of the European airspace and its consequences.

I will not dwell on what has already been said, especially when it comes to the magnitude of the colossal, abysmal financial impact, one might be tempted to say, of this crisis in direct or indirect terms.

While I am pleased to consider the possibility of granting exceptional public aid to the air sector, which has already been heavily approved since September 11, 2001, I am still perplexed by the European management of events.

Given that 750,000 European passengers have been affected, many of whom are still stranded around the world, and given that the economic losses are increasing exponentially with time, how can you explain that it took no less than
Not one, two, three or four, but five days for European transport ministers to meet by videoconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
2. No one disputes the need to apply the precautionary principle as an absolute priority. But today, as traffic is gradually being allowed back into certain areas,
With the weather unchanged and the volcano still active, we are entitled to ask ourselves what additional safety guarantees for passengers could have been provided earlier, more quickly.

3. An evolving action model has been developed. The evolution according to the weather, the activity of the volcano can change from hour to hour, who will continue to carry out the updated assessment of the safety of the corridors.
Should these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this persists, worsens or recurs, which is likely, the management model that is put in place will have to provide for greater coordination of Member States and special operational procedures based on real data, better

coordination of other means of transport in exceptional circumstances, but also taking into account the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of tens of thousands of stranded passengers who also have the right to information and assistance.
So far, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.

Thank you, Madam President. I would like to express my thanks, in turn, after other speakers, to our colleague, Mr. Méndez de Vigo, who has done remarkable work under sometimes passionate and always interesting conditions.
The debates within the Constitutional Affairs Committee lasted a long time. They were up to the task and up to the intensity of the interest that the parties obviously have.

European Parliament, in the major subject that concerns our first head, in a perfectly legitimate way, the composition of our Assembly and the modalities of designation of the members of our Assembly.
Once again, the rapporteur was able to gather opinions and contributions that were sometimes different and synthesize, I would say, in a very balanced text, the opinions and the contributions.
I wanted to thank him.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both the one concerning the convening of the CIG and the one concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our Assembly, are marked by realism, pragmatism and effectiveness.
I believe that this is, overall, what citizens expect from Europe on other subjects as well.
Mr. President, Mr. Dali, Mr. Commissioner, it is with great force that this draft report, as presented just now by Mr. Peterley, takes up the lines
Director of Communication of the European Commission and also inspired by the resolution of the European Parliament of April 10, 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to support the objectives of the European partnership envisaged by the European Commission to fight cancer more effectively, whether it be the importance of prevention and early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and above all the reduction of inequalities within Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed in the European Commission's communication and in the draft report.
I would like to commend the work done by Mr. Péterli, the rapporteur, in the context of drafting this report and the compromise proposals put forward to incorporate the various amendments.

As a fictitious rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat group, I would like to emphasize, among other things, the following issues. First of all, the increase in annual deaths due to cancer caused by exposure to carcinogenic agents in the workplace, but also the importance of better access to information.

information on medicines for cancer patients, but also the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular updating of substances of very high concern, which includes carcinogenic substances, support for initiatives aimed at preventing the import of goods

containing carcinogenic chemical substances and to strengthen the control of the presence of chemical substances within the European Union. And finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that can include people suffering from chronic diseases or cancer.
Here are the questions we wanted to ask while supporting this report project.
Yes, thank you Madam President. The oil drilling leak in the Gulf of Mexico is a true ecological and economic catastrophe.
It would appear that irregularities were found in the granting of forest permits by the United States Department of the Interior.
This would be an unforgivable oversight, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not only concern the United States of America.

When we know that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states around the world, if these permits are granted with the same carelessness, this would pose a real serious problem to the whole world.
Elected officials from European ultra-peripheral regions and from the PTOM, which are almost entirely islands, nearly 130.
In total, spread over the three continents, I must say here my very great concern for our islands with regard to offshore oil exploitation projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, as a role model, should review with the utmost rigor the safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
Moreover, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily caused by Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tons each year.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that offshore platforms now fall under the authority of an undisputed international scientific authority that should be set up in the form of an international authority?
After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honored to initiate a genuine global governance for the research, protection and exploitation of marine resources.
Continuing the Barcelona process, the Union for the Mediterranean is an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the East and South of the Mediterranean basin.
And as the excellent report by Vincent Payon points out, we cannot ignore either the potential of this region or the dangers it carries.

However, let us have the lucidity to recognize that since the bombing of Gaza and with the continuation of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is in a deadlock.
The political aspect is blocked.
We are not even sure that the summit planned for next June in Barcelona will take place.
I would not be surprised if we learn in the coming hours or days that it has been postponed sine die.
We must not give up, however. But the European Union must take on more responsibility in seeking a political solution.
We cannot leave the United States with the monopoly of the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, while we are content to contribute to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean are key to our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best tool at our disposal.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this is an extremely important subject concerning consumer protection.
A recent survey indicates that the food safety situation has deteriorated over the past ten years in the eyes of Europeans. One in three consumers remains wary of the quality of products.
Therefore, updating, simplifying and clarifying the labeling of food products in the European Union is a requirement for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
As for the color code, we are in favor of this color code if it is accompanied by a reference to nutritional values expressed as a percentage.
And I am opposed to mandatory nutritional declarations for wines and spirits.
We wish to develop a specific regulation for wine and spirits within the next three years, instead of the five years proposed by the European Commission.
That is what I wanted to point out, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Mr. President, Madam High Representative, this attack on civilian ships by Israeli commandos obviously requires an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credit could we give to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack took place in international waters, it therefore concerns the international community, it particularly interests Europe, which borders the Mediterranean.
Europe should make itself heard more and get more involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill that we are showing is not enough.
We must also express a political will and take the means to make ourselves heard.
The brutal boarding of the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army has caused emotion and condemnation.
Emotion over the nine victims of the attack on civilians, condemnation as this recklessness in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.

By doing so, the Israeli government is penalizing its people, because in the end, we see that the ultimate goal of security in the region is moving further away with the strengthening of the extremes.
Yes, more than ever, the Israeli government must renounce the policy of force.
However, I would like to point out that the strong media coverage around the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation seems necessary to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
I wish that the Israeli government accepts that this investigation includes substantial international participation so that justice can finally be found in this region. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the Partnership for Modernisation and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it were only for that, would at least have the merit of highlighting how Russia is an unavoidable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive statements on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
However, a few remarks.

While the Union's requirements are always put forward, the interests or positions of its partner seem to be systematically undervalued or scorned, whether it is in the field of energy or in the way it can analyze the Eastern Partnership and the Atlantic aspirations of its closest neighbors.
I also note that the firmness shown by most Member States and the Union in their speeches, the virulence of the condemnations of human rights violations, seems to be reserved for Russia alone.

The statements are more guarded, the diplomacy more muted, as if it were about China, for example, and its systematic violations of the rule of law, even on the subject of the Laogai, this global factory, in view of the minimum European social requirements, when our French or European workers are unemployed.

Allow me to remind you of the adage "Ad angusta per angusta", "to the heights by narrow paths", for that is how I see the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that for so many decades bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Confederation has managed to raise the head of an entire nation despite the difficulties and the important challenges that remain to be met.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen Europeanists, especially since the European super-state does not achieve any of its beautiful objectives despite increasingly costly means and the progressive domination of the states of Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but recall that this Assembly was more lenient towards the Soviet Union, which was more communist, than it was towards Russia.

They are often the same people who yesterday advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for participation in Mr. Gorbachev's common home, who today express the most virtuous indignation and the greatest modesty towards the Union-Russia partnership.

On this subject, I must inform you, if you are not already aware, of new historical facts that will emerge due to the progressive translation of the secret Soviet archives that a courageous Mr. Pavel Stroilov has managed to obtain. These archives have already provided, and will continue to provide, a great deal of information.

An unpleasant surprise for the classic of the single thought as to the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was really Mr. Gorbachev, and the betrayal of the European powers of today, who wanted then with enthusiasm to make possible certain Soviet projects.
I risk repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.
This country is much closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests or common risks than some states that you are about to make join the European Union.
Mr. President of the Council, it is often said that necessity is the mother of invention.
Faced with the crisis, an obvious fact, that of a necessity that has become ineluctable, that of innovating, of being creative.

In this regard, I am pleased with the work done by the Council, a step that I hope will ultimately be a giant step, leading us towards true economic governance, for let us not be mistaken, the simple coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Could we achieve a real budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves decided to do so?
Let's get back to the Council's decision, which still makes me happy.
The strengthening of the preventive aspect of the Stability and Growth Pact is a good thing, but there is no real budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who deviate.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified, which is a pity.

Otherwise, I would like to express my satisfaction, among other things, with the directions taken, such as the famous competitiveness evaluation dashboard, because that is what it is all about, reconnecting with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
It also praises the project to establish a banking tax, the acceptance of a tax on financial transactions, the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, all these decisions and orientations seemed, a few months or even weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, even really hypothetical.
You are right, it is true, it is a profound cultural change on the scale of European small steps policy.
That said, it is now mandatory that in October, the States implement these guidelines in a very concrete way.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant step or simply a pious wish, which we will all bitterly regret, and in particular a majority, the citizens, will have to endure on a daily basis. Thank you.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this Gallo report and, apparently, Parliament, all the groups still need to discuss because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we asked to postpone the debate and the vote on the Gallo report, that is to say in September, September 2, or that will have to be seen at the Conference of Presidents.
So it's a very simple thing.
Since the fruit is not ripe, let's let it ripen over the summer and discuss in September.

Thank you, Madam President. I must admit that I have difficulty following my colleagues who like to show off their muscles and claim the monopoly of our legitimacy vis-à-vis the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But when the members of this House, through hard work and conviction, assert a reasoned position, when
We are defending what looks like a general European interest against tense states, the situation changes from one extreme to the other.
In this debate on European supervision, Parliament has played this role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Committee, of which I am the shadow rapporteur for my group, I defended, as rapporteur, Mrs. Goulard, an ambitious line.
I took mechanisms ensuring a certain effectiveness and I insisted on the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is the only community institution in this set and because it has shown its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I will not mention the names of all the institutions and all the great figures who suddenly disappeared during the storm.
We can consider ourselves lucky to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow macro-prudential supervision attached to a strong community institution, while micro-prudential supervision will necessarily remain fragmented.
In order to avoid any trouble, the European Systemic Risk Committee must start working as soon as possible.
The future will show whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to start from a sound basis, as systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. The final agreement on the reform of the directives relating to industrial emissions is more than acceptable and I commend the work of compromise that has been done.

This final package takes up the key points of the position that I defended with several of my colleagues within the Environment Commission, and which aimed to make this text ambitious but realistic legislation.
Firstly, maintaining a certain flexibility for businesses and competent authorities for granting exemptions.
Then, I would like to praise the new version of the SN, which is so controversial and which, now limited to certain sectors, seems much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better coordination with the ETS directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the idea of creating a market for SO2 and NOx quotas, which is not very relevant.
However, there are a few caveats to keep in mind, particularly with regard to the provisions relating to the soil.
With the SOL directive still pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by Member States that have their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached at the end of the trilogues.

A tremendous amount of work has been done on all sides to avoid sending this text to conciliation, a text that I must remind you is of crucial importance both for industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings its load of information that shows us the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico with the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind have occurred elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular about what is happening today and has been happening for a long time in Nigeria.

This is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules regarding the management of platforms, not only European rules, but also international rules.
As far as the European Union is concerned, I think it is necessary that it be equipped in a preventive manner to fight against this disaster, and I think it is obvious
This also means that all of this argues, as Mrs. Damanaki said, for a firm and resolute choice in favor of clean and renewable energies.
And the European Union should set an example in this matter.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur while the European Union is about to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500,000 tons of beef.
A new opening of our market will be to the detriment of breeders in the European disadvantaged areas, without any guarantee of respect for health and social standards.
We cannot accept that.
Europe buys 38 million tons of soybeans for livestock feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize more than 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, Bunge.
Between 2001 and 2004, soy destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forest.
It was one of the main causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on regaining autonomy in plant protein for livestock feed.
Environmentally friendly agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be reduced to nothing by this bilateral agreement project.
Once again, the European Commission is selling out its agriculture and its farmers to obtain uncertain concessions for service companies.
These concessions will not serve the farming families of Mercosur in any way, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be convinced, just read the Tyson Group report. Tyson is an American company, a heavyweight in the international meat market.
who announces having invested in Brazil to, I quote, and it is in its report, "use this country as an export platform for Europe."
Other companies, such as Doux, had already anticipated this approach by buying the Brazilian group Frangosul in 1998.
Many poultry farmers, especially in Brittany, had been the victims of this operation.
Europe, without wanting to continue its policy of delocalization by increasing its attacks,
Against the peasants, we must stop
Yes, Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture that could result from the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur.
My group and I share these concerns.

Indeed, there is reason to fear, and as a deputy from an outermost region, I have experience with the banana agreements. There is therefore reason to fear that an agreement with Mercosur could be difficult for many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
There is also a risk that this agreement will turn the agriculture of Mercosur too much towards a productive agriculture to the detriment of small farms that exist in these countries.

A balance must therefore be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers anchored essentially on the dogma of mercantilism. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr. Rowe.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would simply like to tell you that we perhaps did not do our agenda well today.
If we allow free trade agreements to enter the European territory, products that do not respect our social standards or our environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be useless.
Very clearly, we cannot remain in a state of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental constraints, health traceability and security,

On the one hand, we impose restrictions on our farmers under the pretext of protecting consumers, and on the other hand, we allow products that can freely enter our continent without respecting these same restrictions.
The question that is asked behind the negotiation with Mercosur is precisely that.

And the way things were initiated, whatever we are told about the fact that Parliament was very well informed and that things happened with the greatest transparency and clarity, does not lead us to give a positive assessment of a negotiation that is taking place while, in parallel, negotiations are continuing at the WTO.
In the name of consistency, consumer protection and the protection of our farmers, I do not believe that we should continue in this direction.

Thank you, Madam President. I would also like to commend the work done by the rapporteur, Mr. José Bové, commend the Commissioner, and then the intervention of Mr. Dess, who preceded me, on the objectives of this report.

I think it is very important that we keep in mind that in the debate we are having, we have to solve a problem related to the volatility of agricultural prices and especially to the fact that when prices...
When they increase, they are quickly passed on to the distribution level. But when prices fall at the production level, there is no impact on consumers.
So there is indeed an issue with the organization of the sector, there is indeed an issue with the distribution of what is called the added value within the sector.

And I think that the José Bové report offers, on several points, perspectives that must be highlighted, and here I am really addressing the Commission, to try to get out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first one, of course, is the organization of the sector and the balance of power within the sector.
What are the proposals that we are making so that producers can come together, organize, and have more weight within the supply chain to negotiate?
This is the question you raised, Mr. Commissioner of Interprofessional Affairs, but it is also a question raised about the contractual basis that will be put in place.
And I plead, and it is in the report, that this contractual base is a European framework.
We cannot let each country solve this problem.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
This is a proposal, a lead that is inseparable for me.
Secondly, of course, the question of price transparency.
And on that, I am in favor of setting up this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers of the evolution of prices.
So, I support the proposals that are being made and I hope, as Mr. Dess said, that there will be a majority to follow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to welcome this debate today, which once again highlights the need for the Union to appreciate and value its regional diversity.
In this time of negotiation of the new 2014-2020 framework programs, it seems important to me to highlight the arrangements that specific regions should benefit from.
The issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the heart of our concerns.
However, the development of mountainous, island or sparsely populated areas requires more than a set of derogatory measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We must put in place the instruments capable of making coexist in synergy all the domains of community action in order to reinforce their added value.
Moreover, as a representative of the outermost regions, I am eagerly awaiting the new strategy of the Union for the outermost regions, which the Commission's services have promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues, first of all, I join the position of my colleague on the absence of the Council at this meeting of the Parliament.
I find that a little bit careless on the part of the Council, I also want to say that.
As the next summit on October 6 approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely try to make progress together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at the same time, we were already busy in this same hemicycle urging Europe to do everything to achieve an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We saw that the result was not up to our expectations and ambitions.
So, the concerns one year later are the same, if not even more intense.

So that we can today constrain or convince our partners, we must show that our determination is absolutely intact, show for example that we have the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the South.
To this end, the implementation of innovative financing, and I heard yesterday the speech of President Sarkozy at the UN, becomes a necessary evidence.
For example, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be excluded.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that do not go far enough in their commitment to climate change, and much more than a threat, ultimately. And a way to protect our jobs and our businesses, especially to better address the post-crisis.

Thank you, Madam President. For me, the need to revalue family leave is not proven. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we should not be totally demagogic in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially of two kinds. One, the economic context, it's true, but not enough to leave millions of families in limbo for decades. Two, the legal gaps in the report, since the text contains several types of family leave whose legal bases are not reconcilable.
Let's take adoption leave, which is mentioned in the text on the same level as maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the desire to give equivalent rights to those of biological mothers.
I am in fact the additional small package that Mrs. Morin mentioned, to be added to the Estrella report.

If the objective is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of women, of all women on the job market, then adoptive mothers, who have become mothers on the same basis as others, are entitled to the same rights and the same protection at work.
They are mothers like any other, in every respect. They adopt a child, whether it is more or less than 12 months old, by the way, no discrimination please, as it is stated in the text.
As for adoption, I regret that the text was not studied in depth.
It was not even fed by the Rambol impact study.
All this has not been well achieved, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these drawbacks, I will support Mrs. Estrella's report, because beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parenthood in a society of...

more and more resigned to the education of their young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we are not sitting in the Council but in Parliament. If we, the directly elected, are not ambitious, tell me, who will be?
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would like to intervene and not to return to the debate as it has unfolded until now.

We discussed the 2011 budget with the constraints that we know, that is to say, those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with public deficits at the national level that can lead to two hypotheses.
These public deficits at the national level constrain the European deficit, or these deficits at the national level must give a new direction and a new breath at the scale of Europe.
That is the question.
And I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, especially to try to think, when we discuss a budget revision, when we start talking about budget prospects for after 2013, not to...
to remain totally steeped in the context of the crisis. Except to tell me and to tell all the citizens of Europe that, decidedly, Europe will remain in the crisis for a long time.
Our whole problem is indeed managing the crisis and reducing our deficits and our debt, but it is also preparing for the end of the crisis.
And that is where the budgetary question arises.

We will not be able to get out of the crisis, and this has been said by Joseph Daul right away, if the European budget, because it is European, is able to give us the means to regain what we lack today: growth, job creation, innovation, research.

That is the issue. And it is at this level that we need to discuss the budget, and not do as we often do, constantly integrate the issue of the crisis, the issue of deficits. And there, the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even announced in advance a reform of the treaties, without even having discussed with Mr. Van Rompuy about anything, in order to sanction all the states that will not respect a budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we are at the Council level today, while the Parliament is asking for only one thing, and in particular the Commission, which is to try to pull the European project. And this is happening through the budget.
So you have noted a number of things on which we are in complete agreement.
More flexibility is needed.
Obviously, we need to find a way to have a much more flexible budget together. Because it's a necessity, it's Europe's reactivity that is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the effectiveness of the European budget.
We will all agree on this. All agree. It is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other is that we need a schedule. We need to set objectives together, Mr. Commissioner. It can't just be words, commitments, promises.

The texts are very interesting and I agree with them almost 100%. But now we need to get down to specifics, and in particular on an essential question around which we are circling, that of own resources.
How do we get our own resources tomorrow for Europe? Not for Europe, but for all European citizens, and to find together the path of growth and an even stronger path for Europe tomorrow.
It's your turn, Mr. the Commissioner.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation for the next G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers on European economic governance, on the need to strengthen European economic governance, to strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact and to better associate the European Parliament and of course also the national parliaments with the process.
I would like to quickly mention two challenges facing our nations and the G20 members, which should be addressed in the context, in my opinion, of the next G20 meetings.
The challenge of the currency war and that of the volatility of the prices of raw materials.
I think that on these two subjects, which are real threats to global growth and which cause very significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must...

European countries manage to organize themselves, to take common positions, to give themselves the means to speak with one voice during the next G20 summits, in Seoul, but also those that will follow, and more generally on the world stage. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. My dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feio for the quality of the report and for the ambitious proposals it contains.
This also shows that the European Parliament is taking its rightful place in a debate that is crucial for the future of Europe, and we can only rejoice in this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis has been a revealer of the dysfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
So, I take note of Mr. Fayot's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
To do this, I think that the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, and in particular the sanctions.
It is essential if we want a lasting improvement in the budgetary situation of the States, which is not always popular.
It's restrictive, but we have no choice.

Mr. President, I believe that the report clearly shows the stakes that the marine environment represents in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, and research combined with climate change.
It is a considerable development potential that needs to be secured, protected and sustainably enhanced, as the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its outermost regions offer it the world's largest exclusive economic zone.
Given such a finding, it is therefore up to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's leading maritime power that does it, who will do it in its place?
But it must be acknowledged that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
You cannot claim to occupy a leadership position in world politics with only 50 million euros.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, since they are present in all oceans, it would be
It would have been wise to give them a major role in a large ocean strategy, which unfortunately was not retained by the report, and I regret that. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madam, Sir Commissioner, I would like to return to the anti-counterfeiting agreement that is currently being negotiated, in particular with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials of the American patent office.
Moreover, 75 American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He believes that ACTA, a simple executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
While the European Parliament is about to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, as you know, it still raises great concerns and is far from being unanimous.
I think it would be useful to have a very clear response from our American counterparts on two points. Can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
In their eyes, is ACTA a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement, which China, India and Brazil are already absent from, would lose a great deal of its credibility if it were not implemented by the United States.
Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. Throughout the difficult birth of the directive on alternative funds, I have not ceased to plead for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle sounds good as an obvious fact, but its obviousness has run into countless difficulties.
The result that was presented to us today is satisfactory.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr. Gauzès, who, after this particularly painful delivery for him, deserves a substantial maternity leave.
I would like to emphasize that the issue of the treatment of third countries must be observed in two ways, whether we are inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks in particular to the European Parliament, all funds sold in the European Union will be effectively subject to comparable regulation.
We can therefore more or less talk about a level playing field.
During the transitional period, non-EU entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while EU funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different on markets outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It would therefore be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, as they would be less flexible and more expensive.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was for a time inevitable.

As far as the depositaries are concerned, we should also know that we will make the exercise more binding, in particular because of the new responsibilities that will be incumbent upon them. Their increased cost should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to show my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is not trivial. Its implementation, which is necessary, will also involve difficulties of which we must be aware.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, particularly at the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in the care pathway, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with health professionals and to follow the prescribed treatment to the letter.
Today, patients are demanding independent, comparative information that is tailored to their individual needs.
Unfortunately, the revision proposals for the directive sent by the European Commission did not correctly address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals open the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which seems to us to be nonsense in terms of responding to the real needs of patients.
This operation is of no interest to either the citizens or the member states.
On the contrary, it would mean additional bureaucracy, increased spending and taking risks for patients.
It is for these reasons that we had initially presented a proposal to reject these texts, thus asking the Commission to review its copy.

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Karl Schilter from the Greens group, has enabled our rapporteur, Mr. Fechner, whom I greet, to carry out an important revision of the Commission's proposals.
In parallel, we had submitted sixty amendments aiming to better protect the health of our citizens and to facilitate patients' access to independent, comparative and tailored information.

The adoption of these amendments in the Environment Committee has made it possible to place more emphasis on patients' rights to information rather than making the provision of information an option for the pharmaceutical industry.

In light of the compromise amendments obtained, we have decided to withdraw our position of rejection of the texts, the substance of the text having evolved in a good direction over the last few months.
The draft report, as amended, managed to counterbalance the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to refuse that health professionals be used to distribute to their patients brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies without any control by the health authorities.
Likewise, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, particularly in the field of vaccination.
Information cannot come freely from pharmaceutical companies.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant and, in fact, and I conclude, what happened with the Mediator drug shows how vigilant we must be and ensure that this point of balance, such as we have sought with this report project,

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister. Union and realism will be declined, at least I hope so, during the vote tomorrow of our resolution on this 16th Conference of the Parties on climate change.

I hope that our Commissioner in charge will be able to carry the pragmatic objectives that we will have to achieve collectively, but also defend the sine qua non conditions set by Europe that are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of equity of our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is too little protected will be essential.
Green technologies must benefit the greatest number, but we must not, for all that, sell off our present and future knowledge, even for this essential fight against climate change.

Likewise, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as verification and publication of data, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same scale, seems to be a legitimate request and not a negotiating tool.
Finally, more controversial, and my colleague raised it earlier, the shortcomings of the current system of clean development mechanisms will also have to be put on the table.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, to our regret, that the real negotiating power is not held by the European Parliament.
But the desire of many European deputies, of which I am one, to work and to contribute to a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged and not neglected, as we have felt in recent days.
If Europe wants to be strong in international dialogues, it must be the same for all its legislators.
Thank you, Madam President. The European Union often presents the Economic Partnership Agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
He is also desperate to see these agreements signed as soon as possible.
But the question that we are asking ourselves is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so favorable to them.
Clearly, opinions differ on the quality of these agreements. And as long as these differences of opinion persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
These want to talk about development strategies while Europe often responds with only market opening.
It is this listening that the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly imposes.
I think that the other European institutions should proceed in the same way if we want to build a real strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Thank you. Christians are probably one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, "legitimate targets," and the objective is their simple departure from this region, a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at the Baghdad Cathedral are only the culmination of a situation that we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global player and trading partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation in view of the situation.
Discrimination, whatever its form, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will not be victorious in this region until the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
Colleagues, we are all concerned by the serious crisis currently prevailing in Côte d'Ivoire.

It is obvious that the decision of the Constitutional Council of this country to call into question, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the European Union-ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the ECOWAS, and soon, certainly, the European Parliament, are demanding respect for the official proclamation of the results.

The results of the elections and the installation of the new President of the Republic as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission. The Independent Electoral Commission, which I remind you, is an entity validated by the UN.
All the political groups of the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint declaration, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for any escalation of tensions in the country to be stopped, which could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social and economic disaster for Côte d'Ivoire, which must obviously be avoided at all costs.

Thank you, Madam President. I would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done remarkable work and have added significant value to the European Parliament's text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen initiative that we are about to vote on with enthusiasm at the European Parliament is a major advance of the Treaty of Lisbon.
Let us not be mistaken, this instrument can truly change the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness. I repeat, responsibility and boldness.
It can help European citizens to emerge directly in the European political debate.

It can contribute to the emergence of a European public opinion, that is to say men and women, citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take a position together and come together on truly European issues.
But let's not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our Member States to quickly take the necessary implementing measures. Let us not disappoint our fellow citizens. This is about strengthening European democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to address, in turn, like several of our colleagues, the issue of the persecution of Christians around the world, particularly Christians from the East.
There is no need to recall the horrible acts recently committed.
I would like to recall very solemnly that defending Christians in the East as well as everywhere in the world, pleading for religious freedom, the diversity of cultures,

Believing is pleading for freedom, democracy and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, in any case, we are all convinced here, universal values.
It is really time now, beyond indignation, emotion, solemn condemnations of course, it is really time now to move from words to action.
I therefore call on the European Union authorities, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our leaders, the Ministers of Foreign Affairs,
to take specific measures, to implement a precise, concrete action plan to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr. President, my dear colleagues, Madam the High Representative, we are all in agreement to say that the situation in the Sahel region has considerably deteriorated.
Allowing a lawless zone to establish itself at the gates of Europe is a danger that we must firmly and promptly combat.
Extremist groups are multiplying and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
I, in turn, deplore the loss of life and the taking of hostages and am concerned for the European nationals on the ground.
Until now, Morocco was a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking coming from the Sahel.
Now, drug traffickers, arms traffickers or human traffickers are circumventing Morocco by passing through Mauritania towards the Canary Islands and heading for the European Union.
It is the responsibility, it seems to me, of the European Union to act to help these States put an end to these threats.
The security of Europe is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate vicinity.
It is time for us to act and I ask the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help restore security in the Sahel.
It was said, but I join the marks of sympathy and support that have already been expressed with regard to the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
He represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to say that the European Union, which, as has been said, has been noted for its lack of reaction, must indeed be on the side of the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them achieve the opening of their country to reforms and to establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support the Tunisian leaders in order to engage in a peaceful transition, prepare for the organization of future elections to gain freedom and allow the Tunisian people to find prosperity, development and social peace, an economy that will allow the youth to find employment.

I would say, to conclude, that the Union for the Mediterranean has an important challenge to meet because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave in all the states of the Maghreb, the Middle East and the Near East.
It must implement a strong strategy towards these countries.

But beware, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of the people and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have reminded me several times.

At a time when Europe is questioning a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly rare earths, we cannot neglect the immense potential that intelligent valorization of our waste represents.

Strengthening European standards to improve the operation of collection sectors, addressing leakage or illegal export issues, or even increasing our collection targets, but also must be at the heart of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
The responsibility of the citizen is crucial if we want to implement effective legislation.
And to do so, my dear colleagues, eco-contributions, among other systems, have proven to be one of the most relevant tools.
The manufacturers of electrical and electronic equipment must obviously be more involved in the collection and recycling system, but we cannot absolve the citizen of the waste they produce.
Our citizens must be actors and not spectators of European environmental policy.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would also like to share the remark made by Mrs. McGuinness on the fact that there is an essential link between the food issue and the agricultural issue.
The subject that concerns us is the increase in food prices, with the consequences that this can have on a certain number of populations in the world, but also in Europe.
I would first like to try to share an observation.

The trend of increasing agricultural prices and agricultural raw materials is, in my opinion, a long-term trend that will last for three main reasons: the demographic evolution of the world and the increase in

The world population. Second element, the fact that we are entering, with global warming, into climatic hazards that pose problems, whether it be droughts or floods. And the third point, because the world is also developing,
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are increasing.
So the tension on agricultural markets and agricultural commodities is a heavy trend.
It is aggravated by the volatility of prices. And the volatility of prices is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
And it is on this subject that we must also focus if we want to address both the agricultural and food issues.

And to do this, what the Commissioner said is important. There are two elements. Yes, there needs to be transparency on stocks. But there also needs to be a public policy on stocks, and in Europe, and a management of stocks on a global scale, in particular at the level of the UN.

And secondly, there needs to be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volume to have no connection with the physical quantities that are exchanged on the markets.

We cannot accept that speculators come to speculate on the food issue without taking into account the consequences that this can have, since it is about the food of the world and of humanity. And I finish by saying
This leads me to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy and we reaffirm strategically Europe's commitment to be a food and agricultural player on a global scale.
And secondly, we need to change our development policy so that, on a global scale, and Europe is an actor, we invest again in agriculture, because we will need all agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is rising on the world markets.
We are only at 3% of the 2008 level.
The decrease in production in certain traditional exporting areas is due to climate change. The diversion of cereals for the production of agrofuels and speculation...
The financial authorities that have exacerbated the effects of the rise are responsible for this situation, as shown by the reports of the IMF, the French authorities and as the Commission also says.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely affecting the 1.2 billion inhabitants of the world who live on less than $1.50 a day.
Since October, 44 million additional people have joined the ranks of those living below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those voted in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the American administration has required the limitation and transparency of the positions taken by financial funds on agricultural commodity markets.
This is a step forward to counter the appetites of speculators.
The impact is also dramatic for European breeders.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are bankrupt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per tonne. Today, it is traded at over 300 euros.
The situation has therefore completely changed.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals. It would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must face the crisis, I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of stocks in cereal-producing countries to make them available to farmers at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexing of meat prices paid to farmers on the evolution of the price of livestock feed.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for transferring part of the aid intended for cereals to animal production. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Are we ready in Europe to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there is a but.
The 2009-2010 A(H1N1) influenza episode showed us that each Member State reacted on its own, with little coherence or even solidarity.

As a fictional rapporteur on this case, I think that these findings had to be presented, but above all, we had to go further, be constructive, concrete for our citizens, who, it must be said, and this is what seems most damaging to me, have probably lost a little confidence in public health messages.

The report by Mrs. Rivasi, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into account these fundamental priorities, which include, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States, better coordination with the

European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of European structures for managing health risks, an assessment of the vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
It is therefore a good report, I congratulate the rapporteur. However, it must obviously not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our Member States, which retain the bulk of the powers in this area. It is therefore a real responsibility to be taken towards our citizens.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my deep emotion following the cowardly assassination on March 2nd of the Pakistani minister in charge of Christian minorities, Mr. Shahbaz Bhatti.
This terrorist murder follows many other murders of brave, tolerant, human rights-loving Pakistanis, defenders of human rights and women's rights, I must say.
Once again, we are calling on the Pakistani government to shed light on this cowardly murder and to effectively ensure the protection of people threatened by religious extremists.
I am thinking, of course, first and foremost, but not only, of Mrs. Sherry Raymond.
And I also wanted, once again, to strongly ask all the competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations with a view to...
to prepare future cooperation agreements, in particular the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, a clause respecting religious freedom and respecting human rights. Thank you.
Mr. President, as a reminder, with the crisis and the bursting of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish State had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit, the accumulated budgetary deficit of the central, local and especially social security administrations, was estimated at 32% of gross domestic product in 2010.

If the Irish government, which can hardly refinance itself on the markets, wants to access loans from the mechanism and the European Financial Stability Fund, it will have to meet obligations for social and fiscal changes, while these areas fall under subsidiarity.
In our opinion, this is not contradictory.
As a doctor, I would say that in case of fever, it is useless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without trying to treat the cause.
In the event of the allocation of these funds, it is up to this State to carry out a consolidation of its finances in order to fill its excessive deficit and correct its previous errors.
This austerity plan should improve the GDP by 10% over the next four years.

Just as a bank, without interfering in a person's private life and management, will make its personal loan conditional on a guarantee of solvency, so the European Union can lend to Ireland on the basis of consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in the individual's private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

It is in this way that, by respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, on the basis of a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency is achieved through the reduction of the legal minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions, without exempting fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to decide whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not an open door to interference by the European Union in areas of subsidiarity, which would allow, for example, the dangerous imposition of a European minimum wage, but a protection of the stability of the euro zone through a process of mutual guarantee.

Of course, we need to help Ireland, like other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, especially that of seeing a state unable to repay in the long term, thus weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano in April last year, and many of us said so earlier, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of the European sky.
And each one of us in this hemicycle has been directly concerned.
5 million of their fellow citizens found themselves stuck, with no real alternative means of transport.
And one year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still awaited.

A first crisis exercise, as you said, Mr. Commissioner, related to volcanic ash is scheduled for April 13 and 14, under the coordination of Eurocontrol, ICAO and EASA, but it is essential that EASA takes real leadership for the coordination of security measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the London and Toulouse police forces must be refined using more modern technological means.
As we saw in April, this data can be contradictory and can lead each member state to make decisions regarding the closure of their airspace that are less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the EASA is essential to propose a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as to ensure the centralization and good dissemination of information.
Beyond informing the public, EASA must implement a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving member states, airlines and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all stakeholders will help avoid the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission to be able, with EASA, to quickly present concrete proposals that will fully integrate into the realization of the European Single Sky.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
It's not a revolution. We can't say that everything was bad before and that everything is perfect now.
However, it does present a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.
The main ones, in my opinion, are a better framework for distance sales, and in particular on the Internet. And that is chapter 3. Because we must strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is very useful. It broadens the consumer's choice, allows them to get the lowest prices, and also allows small and medium-sized businesses and craftsmen to find new outlets.
To move forward in this area, it had to be done in a truly European way, that is, on a few very targeted points, to implement a complete harmonization of the rights and duties of each.
Very concretely, it was necessary that an Italian client who buys on a Belgian or German site knows that from now on, he will benefit from the same rights, the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its withdrawal period will be extended to 14 days throughout the Union.
This means that he will know immediately the total amount he will have to pay, without fear of a nasty surprise afterwards.
This means that thanks to the double click, he will correctly verify his order.
Obviously, all this will disrupt certain habits.
In many states, there are subtleties in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, while sometimes they are not even found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to modify one's habits a little in the service of the general community interest.
Let's be clear, this text will still need to be improved and we will have to do so in the coming weeks, with the Council and with the Commission.
And I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work, thanks to our rapporteur Andréa Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the real fruit of this work is mainly the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the internal market of the Union is very fragile.
This political unanimity was needed to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point number 7, after the first paragraph, a first bullet point, guarantee respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the
freedom of speech and assembly, the right to peaceful protest, and to listen to and take into account the legitimate demands of protesters and ensure their safety.

Thank you, Madam President, my dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner. The open sky agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only a step. A step that places Europe in a dilemma.
The Transport Commission and the Commission itself have emphasized this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European companies, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits acquired since 2008.
Let me then draw a parallel with private and professional pilot licenses, a text that will be discussed before the summer. Because the pilots, of which I am one, find themselves in a dilemma.
The European Aviation Safety Agency, wishing to harmonize licenses on European territory, will do so to the detriment of 80,000 to 90,000 general aviation pilots.
directly concerned, some of them holding a single American license, and to the detriment, and this is important, of the companies and jobs related to this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project which has no security basis.
There are 31% fewer accidents among American license holders.

The objectives of the basic regulation text 216-2008 allow for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, the interest of which is not seen in waiting for hypothetical agreements postponed until 2014.
Thus, I propose an open sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I come to Parliament sometimes by piloting myself to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is perfectly safe.
Thank you, Madam President. At this stage of our debate, I will inevitably have to repeat or support some of the things that have been said previously.
But I also wanted to say that, like several of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, which the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be solved by any Member State alone.
No Member State should be left alone to face the challenges it is confronted with and which, once again, in my opinion, are faced by the European Union as a whole.
It is therefore really the European Union's ability to organize and to face up to things in a common, in a solidarity-based way that I am calling for.
I believe that the time has really come now to lay the foundations for a genuine European policy on immigration and asylum.
More than a year ago, a European pact on asylum and immigration was adopted.
Now is the time, I think, to decline it in a very concrete way.
So we have heard you, Madam Commissioner, we have heard a number of recommendations that she was making.
