I wanted to come back to this and strongly support some of these proposals.
Yes, we must at all costs strengthen the means of the Frontex agency.

We need to strengthen the human resources, the material resources, the financial resources of the Frontex agency, to enable it to support the Hermes operations and the Poseidon operations in a more substantial way.
Yes, additional financial means are needed for the Member States that are, I would say, in the front line, in the first place, facing the increased migratory flows that we are experiencing today.
This will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we need to establish closer cooperation ties with the states of the southern shore of the Mediterranean, support them of course, help them, find instruments.
The Commissioner mentioned, I believe she went to Tunisia to discuss it, the mobility partnerships.
Yes, we must strengthen these instruments in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a precise and concrete spirit. Thank you.

Mr. Commissioner, you are no doubt aware that the most heated discussions we have had here around your communication concern the place of public services, services of general interest, in the single market and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your proposal 25 and we are asking you to go beyond a simple...

communication that would not be up to the expectations and needs of the actors, users, and all the stakeholders of public services, and that would not be up to the objectives that you are formulating.
The European Union must convey a clear and unambiguous message on public services.
To do this, we must create a positive legal framework, regulation or directive.
The Lisbon Treaty gives us the legal basis.
It is up to you to translate them into legislative proposals now.
I think that Parliament is ready to follow you in this direction.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their tremendous work on the occasion of this discharge, and I also welcome the presence of the Council for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a question of European identity and it is not only a question of economy.

I am speaking about it today in this hemicycle on the occasion of the debate on the 2009 discharge, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the Budgetary Control Committee as a simple means of saving money.
The question of the Parliament's expenses also interests me.
In this regard, I propose that we hold the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels. This would allow us to make better use of the Parliament's seat in Strasbourg.
And since we want to make savings, I suggest other things, for example, to remove the per diem of Friday from our colleagues, as well as the removal of per diems for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that we do not have to give per diems to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond the scope of budgetary control, even though I commend the important work of Ville, our rapporteur, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are talking about the economy, I also wish that the system of compensation for sponsored groups of visitors be moralized and sanitized.

I do not find it very moral, and it gives a very bad image of our institution, that the group leader is reimbursed in cash, on the day of the visit, without any work, any control of what the group has spent.
Sometimes, the amount allocated, I am informing you, exceeds the amount of actual expenses.

It would be logical for the groups to send a quote in advance to the visits service, for them to receive an advance from Parliament on expenses, and this on a bank account, and for the balance to be paid on presentation of the invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I am addressing the Commission, my colleagues. I welcome the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 80s, but rather a space that has continued to expand in recent years and which now has 25 states, including three non-members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, the Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it covers today, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this sense that the proposals of the Italian and French governments must be read, and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
Mutual trust between the states that are part of the Schengen area is certainly the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties does not respect its obligations and creates air pockets, the whole system becomes faulty.
It should therefore be possible for other States to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly controlled border control.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly invited to better control their external borders.

Moreover, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the Schengen spirit, in that these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be taken at the European level and not intergovernmental.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the set of measures envisaged in the long term in the perspective of a common migration policy.
It is notably essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide more solidarity, I am concluding, to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation that the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years only highlights a shortcoming of the Kishinev.
Two more minutes, Madam President. In a few weeks, migrants from the Mediterranean countries have represented a significant percentage of the annual French immigration.
This acquis is not static but must, on the contrary, evolve.

I hope that these proposals will be quickly adopted in order to guarantee as soon as possible better management of our Schengen area and to ensure the security of our common external borders. Thank you.
Mr. President, the European Union has finally taken sanctions against Syria.
But unfortunately, it seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding challenging the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the demonstrators as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as a leniency that allows them to intensify the repression.
Repression. Such cruel repression that one cannot imagine for a second that Syria could be elected to sit on the Human Rights Council of the United Nations.
United Nations, while today the Syrian authorities are refusing UN observers access to the city of Deraa, the scene of terrible violence against defenceless civilians.

Syria on the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its people, in contempt, precisely, of the values that the Human Rights Council must be the guardian.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avoid such a disaster?

Mrs. Mathieu, one minute and a half. Thank you, Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has done this report on the work of Orfèvre, and I know that it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen the control of their borders and have succeeded.
Whether it is police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy and air, sea or land border control, the latest assessments are very clear.
All the technical criteria are met.
We can only note this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now able to implement the Schengen acquis in terms of technical and personnel.
Moreover, if no obstacle today prevents this enlargement of the Schengen area, we note that a certain number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be subject to strict follow-up, especially with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, because, as you know, mutual trust between the Schengen States is based on the full respect by these States of their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties does not respect its obligations and creates air pockets, the whole system becomes faulty.
I very much hope that an agreement will be reached at the Council in order to welcome these two countries into the privileged circles formed by the Schengen States.
And we all measure in this hemicycle the scope of this type of decision for the citizens concerned.
Once again, congratulations to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
Mr. President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have largely supported this objective, including almost all member states and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that since 2008, several Member States have sought to empty the new Eurovignette directive proposal of its content and to block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur, and I would like to salute Saïd El Khadraoui here, thanks to his tenacity and that of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

Now, admittedly, this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will, for the first time, allow the polluter-pays principle to be put into practice and the external costs of transport, such as noise or CO2 emissions, to be internalized.

So that this Eurovignette is not just a tax, but actually contributes to improving transport in Europe, Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the money collected in modernizing transport modes.
The Parliament also managed to obtain concrete improvements in terms of interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we will be able to adopt this compromise that is proposed to us in second reading and thus open the way to a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.

Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that with freedom and fraternity, there should be equality with the farmers and the countries that have joined, with the countries joining from the East.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe that we have made great strides with this report.
It wasn't easy at the beginning and we were more in a confrontation, but we managed to reach a consensus and that's the most important thing.
This consensus makes it possible to protect the overall project, and I believe that is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have succeeded in this bet, and it was not easy. I therefore thank the rapporteur Morsyades and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the need for equality, justice and fairness between producers and between territories, and I believe that this is important.
We have said very clearly and we have confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, essential for the quality and biodiversity of territories.
I believe that was also fundamental.
The fact that we have introduced this notion of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page on industrial, productivist agriculture, is written in the texts.
We will now have to implement this. It is a condition to make agriculture possible for future generations.
This is not an ideological issue.
Finally, today, the concern we have is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
We will have to answer it clearly.

Now, what we are waiting for is to actually enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate. Because beyond the texts, the great intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are going. And that is what we are waiting for, of course, now.
I would like to end by expressing my anger against Germany's attitude, which has led to a fivefold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was in the budget of the PAC.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest. There are 80 million European citizens who do not eat properly at the end of the month.

Thank you, Mr. President. While the European Parliament can boast of some significant advances in economic governance, I invite my colleagues to show humility, for we are dancing on the edge of the abyss.
Let us be aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament remained inaudible during the Greek crisis.
While we are usually so quick to react to all sorts of events with resolutions all over the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States, to the European citizens.
The second observation concerns the scope of this package.
By voting for what I wish, these six directives and regulations, we will certainly take a step forward for the eurozone.
More towards a discipline that we have so much missed, a step, I say, nothing more, which will show its usefulness in the future.

But all you have to do is look at the heated discussions around the reversed qualified majority to measure the road we still have to travel. Whereas it should be a matter of rules and automatic sanctions.
The mechanism of the reversed qualified majority continues to act on some as a scarecrow.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the left wing continues to reject the principles of good budgetary management against all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are contradictory.
Yes, states must also manage their budget as a good father of the family, but not through public spending stimulus. It is a short-term sweet poison, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the next few weeks are crucial, it is now a matter of refounding an economic union.
We voted this morning, after three years of work, on a very important text for the progress of consumer defense in Europe.
He rightly focuses on online shopping, which could represent 25% of all trade in Europe in 20 years, which is quite considerable.
These services will be cross-border in particular.
They will allow consumers to broaden their choice and also to pay much less.
This is real progress.
For SMEs, for all craftsmen, this is also a very important opportunity to expand their outlets.

Among the main advances, I would just like to mention two: the withdrawal period which is extended to 14 days, and the summary of all the information and the total price to be paid before clicking on the final button to place the order.

And finally, I am proud, in the context of these voting explanations, to say that I, but all of our colleagues, we voted unanimously in the political groups, because on such a subject, it is not controversy that we needed, but obviously consensus.
And we got it.

Mathieu Devinat. Welcome, Commissioner. Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Commissioner, I would first like to commend the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult case, which required a high level of technical expertise, a lot of work and knowledge of the case.
Controlling our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important challenges we face, and technology is more than ever a tool at the service of this challenge.
Indeed, for several years now, we have been able to witness an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some call the digital tsunami will certainly be confirmed in the coming years.
The SIS, the VIS, and Eurodac are essential tools today to ensure the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring good operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This answer is of course very delicate and Carlos Coelho had to face many legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles and he nevertheless managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all the parties involved.
The creation of this network agency indeed appears to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could take over the proper management of these information systems today.

It will improve the management of existing information systems, it will offer better synergy between these databases and will also allow the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this case was the location of the agency. Where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries to have applied to host it.
France already hosts the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, of which it has ensured operational management and administration since 1995, and therefore has total technical control.
Following the conclusions of the European Council of December 2003, which gave priority to the new member states, Estonia also wanted to host the seat of this future agency.

It seems to me that the compromise found is very good. A sort of division of missions, I conclude, Madam President, has taken place by transferring the agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where the tasks of governance, strategy and program design will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness ratio is very balanced and this co-premium solution does not call into question the centralized management of IT systems. Thank you, Madam President.
Mr. President, the transversal social clause and Article 14 of the Lisbon Treaty guarantee social rights, and in particular the right to access public services.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

We must therefore give our social achievements the place they deserve in community law, by recognizing the specificity of SSIGs with regard to competition rules, knowing that these services have a strong local anchorage and are based on actors of the social economy.

The report by Mr. De Rossa is an opportunity to affirm the simple but strong and meaningful principles of equality and universality of access to these services organized collectively, which are factors of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said, it is time to get down to business.
Yes, it is time to get down to business. So I propose that in this debate, we really adopt a European legislative instrument for public services of a social nature.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution submitted by the Greens group.
Thank you, Mr. President. The debates relating to GMOs must imperatively be based on irrefutable arguments, both on the scientific and legal levels.
On the legal level, member states wishing to restrict or prohibit GMOs on their territory needed arguments that were as varied as they were solid.
The rapporteur has broadened the range of margins of error, however.
For this
The scientific basis must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly challenged the scientific assessments of the EFSA, which are always positive towards GMOs, unlike national scientific assessments.

To restore confidence, shouldn't we first, Mr. Commissioner, simply apply the existing legislation, which aims to provide a number of scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council’s recommendations of October 2008 remained a dead letter?
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First of all, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Busuttil for the excellent work he has done.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal and we can only congratulate them.
This report outlines an agency with enhanced resources, better suited to the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have shown us the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex finally has the means to carry out its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and benefit from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very effective.

New tasks are also assigned to them, such as the organization of voluntary returns or the processing of personal data, so that we can fight against cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's field of competence gives us the means to consider and address migration issues with a global approach and not to confine ourselves to a simple mechanical management of borders.
I approve of the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, notably Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its rightful place in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory council within the agency.

I can only praise this comprehensive proposal which takes a step forward towards a healthy and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and continuous. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Meyer, and my colleagues for their sometimes critical remarks. But this 2010 activity report is finally a great opportunity to talk about the Petitions Committee, as it remains too little known.
Yet it is the Commission, which has a direct link, sometimes physical, with the citizen, who can attend our debates himself.
It has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament as well as a very long expertise thanks to its direct relationship with the citizen.
Indeed, any petitioner can go to Parliament and defend their rights before the Petitions Committee.
We can also praise the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases that are often discussed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be, listening to the problems of its citizens and united to find solutions and protect them.
Unfortunately, the means of action and the means of influence remain limited, especially on the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes almost completed.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will be conducting a mission on this topic in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always rush to provide us with all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it carries out, even if sometimes it could go further in the search for the truth.
I must also commend the constructive work we are doing with the European mediator.
I finally call on the citizens. Continue to solicit us through petitions, as directly elected representatives,
Our role will always be to preserve your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, I am pleased with this resolution on homelessness, as it is our responsibility to remind everyone of the extreme urgency of the situation.
First of all, we note that what was a priority yesterday remains even more so today.

The lack of definition and reliable statistical indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from noting that, with the crisis, the number of people living below the poverty line has gone, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to 84 million estimated in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned with eradicating poverty, asked Member States to put an end to the problem of STDs by 2015.
Today, we are even a little closer to our goal.
Has the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, really been used by the Member States to concretely tackle this great precariousness whose urgency has become permanent?
I truly doubt it and I deeply regret it.

To conclude, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a global strategy, a multisectoral strategy for homelessness, because of course there is poverty and lack of housing, but there are also family problems, health issues, various addictions or personal vulnerabilities.
We need a global, effective, ambitious but tailored approach that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their journey and their life setbacks.
It is a right that is at least fundamental, of which many large companies are deprived.
Thank you, Madam President. In recent years, as everyone has said, the European Union has been hit by unprecedented disasters. Listing them here would take up all the time of the debate.
I will still mention the explosion of AZF, the 10th anniversary of which we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A strengthened reaction at the European level, such as proposed in the report by Mrs. Gardini, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity between our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been trying to make this pooling of our efforts operational, and it is high time we acted together and no longer waited for a new disaster to strike our territories before drawing lessons from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our material, human and financial capacities available to everyone in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier you said that we needed to anticipate risks.

It is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding for the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential tool for prevention and coordination of disaster response.
I am calling on the Commission to immediately review this position and support these flagship programs that give Europe an undeniable added value.
Well, I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her very good report.
I hope that we will adopt it. It will thus open the way to European solidarity in the service of citizens. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to increase within the European Union.
More than 43 million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The hour is serious.
Today, these six member states want to end the food aid program without any replacement solution. Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and the Czech Republic.
Of course, there is a decision by the Court of Justice and we must respect it.
However, Mr. Commissioner, the Parliament questioned you in July last year, on the initiative of our group, the Greens, and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the program.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions. But as long as millions of people depend on this system, we cannot let the food aid budget be divided by 4.
The urgency is real.
If nothing is done by the end of the year, more than 300 million euros will be missing from food banks, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to take over to fill this gap.
It is therefore a real question of solidarity between peoples.
Let's not allow an irresponsible minority of governments to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because it is above all a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change the way we produce food in order to bring food production closer to the population, especially the poorest, who also have the right to healthy and balanced nutrition.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will ensure that fewer Europeans need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and let those in need access this vital aid.
I am particularly addressing the future Danish government, which will be responsible for ensuring the presidency of the European Union starting in January.
Come to your senses! Do we need riots at the end of the year in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our approach?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, that's it, there's no one left. Parliament made a strong statement last time, human beings are more important than finance.
Finance, it is high time to reaffirm it.
In any case, we will be very vigilant and will not fail to renew our call in a constructive manner.
Six Member States hold in their hands the fate of 18 million Europeans in need.
Six member states who claim to be doing nothing more than legalism.
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm calls launched by associations that help the most disadvantaged?
And we, European deputies, representatives of all citizens, do we want a Europe where national self-interest dictates policy, with little regard for the citizens of countries in budgetary difficulty?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.

No, let's keep this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but let's not let down those who, in the immediate future, in 2012, are counting on this aid in particularly difficult times of crisis. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I will not go back over the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and in particular in Belgium, in Liège, which will ultimately lead to hundreds of direct job losses and put several thousand indirect jobs at risk.
As a citizen of Liège, I share the astonishment and distress of the 581 workers who have been laid off from their families.
But I also think about the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany and Luxembourg.
The reasons given are always the same: poor prospects for the development of the steel market in Europe, strong competition with imports from China, Korea,
Russia and Brazil, the reduction of the automobile market and finally the competitiveness gap, for example, of the Liege site compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
In addition, and despite a difficult year in 2010, the financial center of the steel group ArcelorMittal Belgium generated a profit of 1.394 billion euros.
He paid 0 euros in taxes, which is a tax rate of 0%.
It is particularly shocking.
The group's management is mainly financial, with a stop-and-go policy practiced on several sites.
And the closure of sites is nothing more in the minds of these leaders than an economic adjustment variable where human issues are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable.
You spoke, Mr. Commissioner, about the rules.
Wouldn’t it be time for the Commission to draw up a binding code of social responsibility for multinational companies?

It has been six years since our Parliament adopted a report on delocalization, the code of conduct for companies, the reimbursement of subsidies, and the mandatory consultation between companies, unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be admitted that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So what does the Commission intend to do about this and by when?
To support the competitiveness of businesses and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we must also adopt a legislative framework.
A strong Europe to face delocalization and restructuring and to ensure full consideration of another capital, human capital.

Finally, for the case of the Liège site, I hope that it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalization Adjustment Fund in order to compensate the workers who have been laid off. Thank you.

Madam President, my dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs that is hitting workers across Europe should lead us to reflect on the role we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational companies that are acting

without any social ethics, which carry out stock market layoffs, delocalize to reduce costs, increase the profits of shareholders, please the rating agencies, in contempt of social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of September 20 on the future of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its desire to support, above all, workers affected by the negative effects of restructuring.
But we also asked the Commission to ensure the consistency between the FEM interventions and the industrial policy of the European Union, in particular through the use of structural funds.

We also ensured that the future FEMIP regulation includes improvements so that the fund does not produce, as it does today, random moral effects on multinational companies, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Mr. Commissioner, we can no longer look at the question of structural funds and the globalisation adjustment fund separately.
Taking into account the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the cost-benefit ratio of a policy, I repeat,
Yes, Mr. President. The European Ombudsman is conducting investigations into complaints against the institutions and bodies of the European Union with great success.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate free movement, that of our businesses and our citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, notably against the detractors of the Union who say too often that the European Union is nothing but a bureaucratic machine without control.
This is clearly nonsense. Europe is doing real work on itself, thanks in particular to the European mediator.
But let me relay a finding that I deeply regret, in which the Commission is under fire.
First of all, there are the figures. 65% is the real figure, and not 12%, of the investigations opened by the mediator concerning the European Commission.

There are also actors. Many companies come to see us to explain their incomprehension in the face of the Commission, in the face of a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, in particular for access to documents. Similarly, with regard to the issue of transparency in decision-making.
Few people can find their way around.
And finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present in the Petitions Committee.
You know, the European Commission gives us its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and that is necessary.

But occasionally, you can see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer a Member of Parliament's question, or who hide behind a wooden language almost as well as politicians, and this in front of citizens pleading their case.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems that the mediator deals with and resolves, there are Europeans who are relieved to be listened to but disappointed by their...
behavior. Citizens who are then negatively marked by their confrontation with institutions, creating perhaps a feeling of revolt, incomprehension and, in the long term, perhaps Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms, as well as those of the mediator against institutions in general, will be heard. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. Professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which the subject of the day is posed.
So we, the PPE group, have given our support to the report of our colleague, Mrs. Matt Larking, a report to the drafting of which we have greatly contributed, and we support, of course, the...

The main recommendation of this report is for more professional mobility, more simplification and efficiency in the procedures for the recognition of professional qualifications, while ensuring the safety of patients and consumers.
But it is indeed in terms of a path to growth that the issue of increasing professional mobility arises.
And indeed, the forum for a single market, which was held in Krakow at the beginning of October, was not mistaken.

who recalled that Member States should recognize the potential of the internal market to boost growth and job creation and should act to eliminate all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
The European Council of 23 October last also set as one of the essential priorities to achieve "smart, sustainable and inclusive growth".
inclusive, the implementation of the 12 priority proposals of the Single Market Act, the 12 proposals made by the Commission, including the recognition of professional qualifications.

We can see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to release the growth potential contained in the internal market, our internal market of 500 million inhabitants, of 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore not only ensure, if we strengthen it, if we modernize it, if we improve the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also allow us to acquire, we hope, additional growth margins.
This is why we have, in particular, I would like to emphasize a practical recommendation, we, the PPE, have particularly supported the implementation of a voluntary professional card.
Thank you, Madam President. I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Kasmarek, for his excellent work.
I would like to say that it is important that each year the European Parliament draws up a report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, given that
This assembly plays a key role in strengthening North-South dialogue and in implementing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 was a rich year for the APP, which met twice, as the predecessors said, in Spain and in the DRC, to exchange, in particular,
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis or even on the freedom and independence of the media and food security.
But in 2010, the APP also sent its first election observation mission for this legislature.
I had the honor of co-chairing this mission in Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague, Assarid, a deputy from Mali.
This election observation mission was a real success.

We were able to meet all the political actors concerned and, thanks to the dual origin of this delegation, which is both ACP and European, we embodied a different legitimacy from European or African missions.
I therefore invite the APP office to renew this experience, which allows us to put into practice the solidarity and privileged relations that unite the European Union with the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his report.
Indeed, the crisis is economic and financial, but it is above all a social crisis for our fellow citizens.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by 20 million by 2020 requires strong measures involving the different levels of public authorities.

We must more than ever keep the commitments made by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion, and during the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must make European funds permanent and optimize them, and in particular the program to help the most disadvantaged, which is currently maintained, improve social protection, support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought on a horizontal level, and it is now time to act to allow the most disadvantaged to escape their precariousness.

As political leaders at the European, national and local levels, we must take the necessary measures to ensure that they have access, without discrimination, to housing, healthcare, justice, education and a first job with a minimum income that can be indexed according to the poverty rate of each Member State.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation and in the reduction of poverty will enable us to implement a strategy for sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth.
The Europe we want and need today is a Europe of solidarity.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs. Levine, for her excellent work.
As rapporteur for the Development Committee, I am pleased that the Fisheries Committee has taken on board the elements contained in our opinion, as it is crucial that the development dimension
be taken into account in measures aimed at combating illegal fishing at the global level, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, the fight against illegal fishing requires global solutions and the involvement of all states, including developing ones.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of the States be also taken into account in the actions to be taken.
Indeed, we cannot impose the same constraints without accompanying measures on developed or developing countries.
For example, small island states have very limited capacities.
We must therefore support them in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
This is why the Union will have to increase the financial envelope in favor of the fishing sector when it concludes agreements in this area with developing countries.

Moreover, it is crucial that measures aimed at combating illegal fishing be implemented, as this practice harms the development of countries by reducing the financial resources that these countries could derive from fishing activities.
However, these resources are essential for developing countries to implement social, economic and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union promote, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the beneficiary states of the aid.
Having a holistic approach is necessary to stem the tide of illegal fishing. Thank you.
Yes, thank you Mr. President. I would like to say that, in large part thanks to its outermost regions, the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This is a major asset for Europe. Also, the development and implementation of a major policy for the sea, oceans and marine depths are essential for tomorrow.
But I fear that with 20 or 50 million euros, this will not be sufficient to achieve this great challenge.

The fight against illegal fishing is part of this major policy. And it is urgent, at the European level, to find an adequate solution to this problem, especially in the case of international cooperation.
I also note that the maritime areas of Guadeloupe, Guyana, Martinique, Mayotte and Réunion are regularly violated and plundered.
Since the report does not mention it, I am taking this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this particular problem.
Good morning Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the Polish presidency for its dynamism and commitment.
Next week, at the Council, our Heads of State and Government will have to make essential decisions for the future of the Eurozone and for the future of the Union.
They will also have to seriously address the issue of stimulating growth.

That said, we can see that today, financial stability has become the priority of priorities, and that the pressures, the tensions exerted from outside the eurozone countries, but also within the eurozone, are ruining our credibility, undermining confidence.
And to hope for the return of confidence, we must restore financial stability, break the terrible progression of national deficits and sovereign debts.
Financial stability has indeed become the priority of priorities, it has become a burning obligation for all.
Our democracies have all committed to very courageous programs to clean up their public finances and reduce their debt, but financial stability is also a prerequisite for any recovery of growth.
But who says solidarity, who says financial stability, budgetary discipline, because that goes hand in hand, of course, must also say solidarity.
We believe it is important to ensure this dual movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.
Be careful not to relieve our democratic institutions of their responsibilities.

Rather than thinking about resorting to a judicial mechanism, I would say, to sanction in the event of budgetary drift, think rather about control and sanction mechanisms exercised by democratic institutions.

To be completely honest, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister of Foreign Affairs. And frankly, even though I belong to the same political party as him, I am not constantly, I would say, in a position to relay the statements of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs.
To be completely honest, I am not aware of any recent statements by Alain Juppé in this regard.
I simply think that France's current position is to assert and reassert without ceasing that the euro is truly the heart of our European construction, that safeguarding the euro means...

The safeguarding of this common project is the safeguarding of the European Union. And in this movement to safeguard the euro, we must of course think about the future, think about protecting young generations and preserving peace on our continent.
Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, tomorrow we will be voting for the third time on the new cooperation instrument.
development which provides support measures in the banana sector for the ACP banana-exporting countries following the reduction of their tariff preferences, the BAM.

In addition, we have a statement from the Council on the next multi-annual financial framework, specifying that the latter would duly take into account delegated acts in external aid instruments after 2013.
Finally, in its resolution, the Parliament specifies, and this point seems to me to be capital, that it is in no case a precedent.

I would like to tell you that I am back from Togo, where the 22nd session of the APP-ACPUE was held, and I believe I can tell you that our ACP friends are counting on us, given the urgency of the situation.
The funds should have been released two years ago.
We must be aware of the deplorable consequences for the ACP partner if the Cotonou Agreement were to be rejected.
The situation of some farmers is dramatic. We can no longer wait and must act accordingly.
I am therefore counting on you to support the text. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. Our coordinator, Mr. Berman, cannot be present tonight for personal reasons.
However, I know that he completely shares my analysis on this file.

The conciliation on this legislative package was long and tedious, and if the result on the human rights and ICAI+ instruments is satisfactory, we are far from the mark concerning the banana instrument.

Thus, the compromise reached on this text dismisses with a wave of the hand the mandate that had been given to our negotiating team, which was to place the Parliament on the same level as the Council on all programming decisions concerning the choice of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
For it is indeed the powers of our Assembly and the very spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon that are at stake here.
The choice of programming priorities is a highly political decision on which our Assembly must have a say.
By categorically refusing to recognize any control power of the Parliament and by using shameful blackmail, the Council once again shows a condemnable ideological retreat.
But the Member States must understand that the European Union's external action is now a shared competence between our institutions.
That is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal under the Banana Instrument.
This is the only way we have to show the Council and the Commission that Parliament wants more transparency in community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurdity would be that we would have to wait for a new treaty to finally obtain the powers that the Lisbon Treaty already provides.
Mr. President, at the risk of shocking the most federalist among you, I believe that a defense policy is a policy that is eminently national.
It meets the strategic, diplomatic and security needs specific to each nation.
The sharing of capabilities is nothing more than an amputation of sovereignty. The single market for military equipment is a vast joke, when certain member states, believing that their
Defense, which is guaranteed in Washington, is primarily equipped with American materials, Europe being unable in this field, as in so many others, to impose community preference.
As for the common security challenges of the Member States of the Union, there is nothing that can be resolved by intergovernmental cooperation, outside of any intervention from Brussels.

I am sorry, but entrusting these areas to Ms. Ashton would be tantamount to recognizing that Moody's and Standard & Poor's have the legitimacy to judge our economic policies, to accept that the Merkel-Sarkozy couple can impose on 27 peoples a German Europe, a pure mental aberration.

For 30 years and even more, since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defense budgets have been the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary rigor, to the point of rendering most of our military tools obsolete.

deficient or obsolete. And this, for purely financial considerations, each one expecting from the neighbor or the supposed big American brother the efforts that he is no longer willing to make himself.
But you are mistaken, my friend.

It is only by returning to independent and resolute national policies that we will be able to equip ourselves individually with the means necessary not only for our national security and interests, but also for the cooperation of these means to meet common challenges.
The addition of weakness and lack has never made a strength.

Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to express the support of the French delegation of the PPE group for the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Governance in the Economic and Monetary Union and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Let us not be mistaken.
This treaty represents an important step towards greater economic and budgetary integration, towards greater financial stability.
Let's say it here.
There can be no sustainable recovery of growth and employment without a cleanup of our public finances.
Of course, growth cannot be decreed. It is not a treaty that can, on its own, revive growth.
But a treaty, that is to say a set of rules and mutual commitments, can bring confidence and accountability.

And since the president of the socialist group thought it appropriate to introduce politics into this chamber, and by alluding to the upcoming French presidential campaign, mentioning the socialist candidate for this French presidential election, I wanted to respond.
