Madam Ashton, good day. Madagascar is one of the poorest countries in the world, experiencing a political crisis whose outcome will depend on the implementation of the roadmap leading to presidential and legislative elections.
The growth of this country is negative.
In normal times, our contribution is around 50% of this country's budget.
The European Union rightly suspended its budgetary support for the 9th and 10th FEDs, but not for the OMDs.
In the meantime, the population is suffering and the companies established in Madagascar are sometimes forced to contribute despite themselves.

While supporting your position, we wish that you weigh in with SADC so that the legal and judicial mess concerning the return of the former president is resolved as soon as possible, as it is one of the most sensitive elements in the application of this roadmap.

I would like to have your opinion on the subject and also let you know that the European Union-Madagascar Friendship Group that we have just created in the European Parliament is available to work with you and the Commission in the interest of the Malagasy people and in defense of the values of our Union.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Iturgaiz, for the quality of his work, for the long negotiations he had to conduct and for the patience he has shown.

We are finally coming to the vote on this report, which is extremely important, as it allows us to bring to this chamber, to the Commission and the Council, the difficulties and fears of our fellow citizens.
Here is further proof, if any were needed, of the effectiveness of the right to petition in Europe.
Petitions on the environment are in the majority, and waste is a major concern for our fellow citizens.
This topic should address a social issue.
We consume everything.
We are only now realizing that what we do not consume, we throw away.
This awareness must be absolutely reinforced among citizens, that's clear.
But this report is also a reminder for the Member States.
It is still worrying to see that the States seem to be unable to control the situation.
Only six Member States have transposed the Waste Directive, the Waste Framework Directive, to date.
The number of complaints received on the subject sometimes demonstrates the lack of transparency in the choice of landfill sites.
Finally, and this is the most worrying, organized crime seems to be doing as it pleases.
A 75 billion euro market is bound to attract covetousness.
States must send a strong signal.
Sanctions against companies that divert public contracts to enrich themselves must be increased.
This report is a warning to the States, but the European Commission must also play its role and check the proper application of the waste directives.
This file must be made visible, but also credible.
If no one plays the game, we will continue to waste time and money in verification and counter-verification procedures that could last for years.
Let us listen to the petitioners’ message and stop this waste more quickly.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr. Nicholson for the courage he has shown in front of the Council and the Commission.
However, I fear that what we have achieved will not allow a balance between producers and industrialists.
This agreement reminds me of the illusion that we know, that children tell, of a paradise where vegetarian lions would eat grass next to sheep.
I don’t believe it for a second. Since 2003, Mrs. Fischer-Bowl has done everything to destroy the dairy quotas in an ideological way.
In October 2009, the Court of Auditors nonetheless recognized the effectiveness of these milk quotas.

Today, we are in a situation that is going to be even more dramatic, and we can see what is happening currently in Denmark, where the most solid farms, with the increase in production, are all in a state of bankruptcy, with a 40% drop in land prices.
Do we want that for the European level?
I say no, we must master production with the participation of public authorities. Thank you.
Madam Commissioner, the standards for the protection of personal data of third countries still differ considerably from European standards.
However, it is our duty to ensure that our minimum European protection standards, of which we are proud, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is essential that personal data be processed fairly and collected for specific and legitimate purposes.
European citizens must be able to see their right to access and rectify personal data concerning them guaranteed, as well as to file a judicial appeal in the event of a violation of their rights.
We must act to allow European and international standards to coexist and resolve a potentially harmful legal conflict for European citizens.
European legislation alone is not enough.
It must be articulated and coexist intelligently with international standards, as we cannot rid ourselves of our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this Assembly.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the implementation of a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism.

Such a system would allow us to have a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting internal law and therefore the protection of the personal data of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully assume their protection standards. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent more than a year strengthening its economic governance to avoid macroeconomic imbalances and budget deficits that are too large and threaten the European economy, but this has not prevented social exclusion or the increase in unemployment.
It is time, no, it is now urgent that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy be an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States in a growth perspective.

Each state will have to implement a national employment plan, which means that the emphasis should be placed on so many subjects, such as, in no particular order, training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeship, paid internships, etc.

However, and Commissioner Andor reminded us of this earlier, we have 23 million unemployed people in Europe, but also 23 million SMEs and 23 billion euros of European funds dedicated to employment and not used.
We could almost make it a 23-23 strategy.
And that’s not counting the 60 billion euros of cohesion funds that have not been allocated.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been taken and have proven their effectiveness, based on flexicurity.
Let us draw inspiration from it.

This also means that our social policy as a whole must be more adapted, with more advantageous social incentives than those related to unemployment and active support for all socially virtuous companies.
We had poverty reduction targets to be achieved by 2020, but we already know that they will not be met due to the lack of strong and appropriate measures taken by the Member States.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be fully exercised, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy used to take strong economic governance measures also be applied to ambitious, effective and binding social governance measures.
Thank you, Madam President. Undoubtedly, the cause of women owes a lot to Europe.
The principle of equality between men and women was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has been reaffirmed ever since in the various treaties.
Gender equality is truly a fundamental value of our European project.
As a result, Europe has always worked in a very determined way for gender equality, for the cause of promoting women.
Little by little, progress was made.
Many legislative instruments have been adopted, guidelines have been put in place.
For many years now, our Parliament has had a very active and vigilant Women's Rights and Gender Equality Commission.
A European Institute for Gender Equality has been created.
Programs are put in place, financial resources are voted on year after year.
More recently, on March 2nd, we had the opportunity to celebrate, for its second edition, the European Equal Pay Day, the day of equal pay.
European Equal Pay Day. Undoubtedly, the legislative arsenal exists, the European will has been concretized on several occasions.
However, it must be acknowledged that the fight remains relevant, the fight for equality between men and women and in particular for equal pay.
There is still an average wage gap of 17% across all European Union countries.
Women still earn 17% less than men for equal work.
This is, of course, completely unacceptable.
The Women's Commission of Parliament is currently working on a resolution project to call on the European Commission to review the 2006 directive on gender equality.
Treatment, which is one of the most worrying battles and at the heart of the concerns and demands of European women in all our societies.

On another subject, that of the establishment of quotas, quotas both within the decision-making bodies of large companies and within political life, I come from a country, France, which adopted this a long time ago, more than 20 years ago.
10 years ago, binding rules on quotas in political life and more recently, about a year ago, a law to establish quotas in the boards of directors of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislation.
So, what is the balance after a few years of application in one case, a few months in the other? We must admit that things have moved, that things have progressed.
So, a necessary evil.
Quotas have an effect.

Madam Commissioner, you have recently taken an important step towards the introduction of quotas at the European level in the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this major public consultation aimed at gathering opinions on the actions to be taken, the legislative actions to be taken.
On this subject, you will have my full and complete support. Thank you.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, on the occasion of this resolution, allow me to address two topics. First, the issue of water management in the world and in Europe.
Europe, and then a question to the European Commission, so that acts can allow to respond to a certain number of our concerns related to the Common Agricultural Policy.
The issue, we know, is water, the big deal of the 21st century.
It is because we will have answers that we will have peace in the world and in Europe.
We know the stakes, we know the stakes in terms of management, we know the stakes in terms of food security.

And on the occasion of this forum, which, as our colleague Rivasi reminded us, too many purely commercial concerns are at the heart of the discussion that has been taking place in recent days in Marseille.
A question: why is there no consistency between water management and water-related resources and the common agricultural policy?
Nothing in the reform of the CAP indicates this management, as our colleague Sarbou said earlier.
So, give us some answers.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Mrs. the rapporteur and our assistants for the work done.
This report now bears its name very well, namely to remove obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a wonderful project, but it is too often noted that it is not yet perfectly defined.
Let's take the economic crisis as an example.
It has revealed our weaknesses and allowed us to build more solidly the institutions for regulating our single market.
For the European citizen, it's the same.
The Petitions Commission, a true complaints office, records the grievances of our fellow citizens every day.
In three days, the European Citizens' Initiative will complete this mechanism.
Despite all our policies that call for mobility, adherence to European values, and exchange, there are still far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.
And a citizen who does not feel European is a citizen who will not vote. It is a citizen who will not see the interest that Europe represents in his daily life.
With my PPE colleagues, we have made a lot of proposals, the most numerous, and I would like to thank them.
It is a report that must produce a sense of belonging and European identity that we must recreate and maintain through these measures.
Our Europe must be a Europe that protects.
Commissioner Viviane Reding has made 25 very concrete proposals in favor of citizens.
They are essential to restore trust between the citizen and Europe.
But the proposals contained in this report reflect other expectations of our fellow citizens. Online shopping, moving, children's rights, employment, the
Citizen participation, healthcare abroad, twinning, the rights of minorities, etc. We still have too much difficulty in fully benefiting from the capacities offered by Europe.
Rights are exercised, demands are heard.
We are the relays here.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 will have to demonstrate to citizens that with free movement, there is also free use of rights in Europe.
I believe that taxation is an interesting tool to change behaviors.

I believe that energy consumption should be in line with an indicative price signal for the consumer. And above all, I think that to avoid any distortion in the internal market, we must try to bring our tax practices closer together.
The principle of proportionality of the different levels of taxation of energy products therefore seems to me to be a necessity.
In the case that concerns us, for example, this would make it possible to put an end to diesel tourism, which we are currently witnessing and which is not an acceptable thing.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission's proposal to review the directive.

However, if we are to achieve our objectives in terms of reducing CO2 emissions or energy efficiency, our collective decisions must not penalize citizens or sectors particularly exposed to the risk of carbon leakage.

Price volatility on world markets, and I am thinking of the agricultural sector for example. The proposal for a directive will have a differentiated impact, depending on the level of taxation of each Member State, but an impact nonetheless on the price of diesel.
The question is, who will ultimately have to bear this increase in price?
Are there any real, practical, realistic, and accessible alternatives for consumers?
As a fictitious rapporteur in the Environment Commission, I support an ambitious but above all sustainable position for all.

I therefore plead for greater progressivity and the implementation of the proposal and its principle of proportionality in 2030, subject to a new impact study updating the one on which the Commission is based and which was nevertheless carried out five years ago.

A few minutes ago, right here, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe due to the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational company present in 9 European member states and which is restructuring its production tool in Europe in the face of declining demand for steel.
Since the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium, in Luxembourg, and the mothballing of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly 6,000 direct jobs are threatened for the year 2012.

Beyond unacceptable practices such as stop-and-go, which should be better regulated, it is the broader question of European steelmaking and adaptation to change that requires extremely urgent answers.

Six months ago, the Commission announced to us the need to shed light on the economic crisis, a new consultation exercise for responsible management of restructuring with social partners and public authorities.
My question is simple: six months later, where are we?
Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would first like to dispel the unfounded allegations of 500,000 to 1 million fake biometric passports circulating in France.
France takes the risks of identity document fraud very seriously.
It does not treat the offenses in this area lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is a crime punishable by one year in prison and a fine of 15,000 euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, which has allowed prefectures to free up additional resources to fight this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud referent is designated.
Moreover, the provisions for the secure issuance of identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, the civil status data provided can be verified between administrative services as much as possible by digital means in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to proof of residence.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path of increased security for proof of residence with the insertion of a barcode.

The classic processing of a title application includes the authorized consultation of useful files, the comparison of all documents produced during previous title applications, the possible authentication of supporting documents.

The security of the issuance of titles is also guaranteed by the double appearance of the applicant, first at the time of the application and then at the time of the withdrawal of the title, as well as the taking of two fingerprints.
Not to mention the reinforced checks for the renewal of lost and stolen titles for comparative purposes with the data kept by the prefectures. I conclude.

Moreover, France notifies international cooperation bodies and in particular Interpol. I am finishing, Mr. President, I have almost finished the passports delivered or lost and stolen so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
My dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, a fact: our fellow citizens increasingly want to find and consume food produced locally and in season, for health and quality reasons, among others.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructure for producers, such as the maintenance of local slaughterhouses, which, while ensuring rigorous health control, allow the development of local short supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers to market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will allow farmers to retain a larger share of the added value created on their farms.
We must encourage and facilitate direct sales within the farm and support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points that offer local consumers a wider range of products.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, the sustainability and the development of direct sales systems by delivery to consumers, such as the AMAPs in France, which allow nearly 3,000 farmers to supply 60,000 families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning the size of the farm, the volume of production or the traditional nature of the product, to define proximity farming. Thank you.

Yes, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues, I am pleased that this rectifying budget concerning the budgetary financing, which was voted on by a large majority in the Budget Committee on March 29,
By financing this overrun, we are avoiding throwing away a strategic basic research project in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we are keeping our international promises.
Let us recall that none of the seven Euratom Community partners has called into question its overall contribution to the project.
Despite the Fukushima drama, Japan has decided to strictly respect its budgetary commitments in ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work and the ITER project would have suffered prejudicial delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITERACAD.
From 2015 to 2017-2018, the building construction and machine assembly phase could mobilize up to 4,000-5,000 people on this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, thank you for the work we have done together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a common political vision on the major environmental challenges for the horizon 2020 and beyond.
This is the whole point of launching a seventh action program for the environment, by putting existing financial frameworks in synergy and by mobilizing new funding resources.
This program must ensure the coherence and articulation between the environmental strategies of the European Union and the sectoral policies, whether it be agriculture,
fishing, research and innovation, health, transport, regional development, land use planning and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is affecting the European Union, we must not give in to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate fields.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, especially with regard to the effective use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and eco-innovation, sources of growth, competitiveness and employment.
It is up to us to promote eco-design, recycling, but also the environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumption choices.
We cannot bypass this environmental education that is necessary for European citizens.
The environmental action program is a political programming tool, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary clarity and predictability to national and local administrations, to citizens, but also to entrepreneurs and investors on the environmental choices of the European Union.
European regulations should not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound changes our world is experiencing today, the EU must reform its Generalized System of Preferences.
Like all compromises, this one does not follow the rule.
If it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial point of view, it is far from being perfect, since we must keep in mind that this regulation is addressed to developing countries.
By developing its new differentiation paradigm, the Commission says it wants to refocus its action in favor of the poorest countries.
This does not seem to be entirely sustainable at first glance.
To do so, the Commission has nevertheless developed a strictly accounting vision based on the sole criterion of GDP per capita.
We can clearly see the limits of this approach.
Many developing countries with middle incomes, whose economies are not very diversified and which are vulnerable to climate hazards.
The compromise reached with the Council does not answer this question, and that is why I call on my colleagues to vote in favor of the three amendments that will be submitted on this text.
Mr. Commissioner, the problem of the availability of public consultations in the various languages of Europe is unfortunately not new.
This is a crucial issue, in my opinion, which is why I have not only asked several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally asked Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its ruling of 20 November 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response, which stated that public consultations do not claim to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this answer, the Commission takes into account the fact that certain positions and views may be over-represented to the detriment of others.
This is not an answer.
I am wondering about the criteria that would allow us to measure the over-representation of the European population.
If written consultations are not representative because they are only available in English, for example, they fail to achieve their goal of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result gives a wrong indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.

If we want to keep written consultations as a tool at the base of the legislative proposals of the European Commission, we must guarantee that they are democratic, transparent and fair for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission chooses to conduct a written consultation, it must take responsibility and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
To conclude, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

We should also integrate into the analysis the too short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the lack of means deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately only accessible to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed regulation aims to give the European Commission increased powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter and the failing states will be forced by the technocrats of Brussels to make budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial balance.
This enhanced surveillance is called guardianship.
States will be punished, fined, spanked, so to speak. Financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even if some amendments aim to prevent the sole budgetary austerity by growth measures, your proposals are only there to make the pill go down.
You know, as well as I do, that growth cannot be decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the technique of the Chinese thief, the bureaucratic, technocratic and totalitarian European state has finished being constituted, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Thank you, Mr. President. Without denying the importance of the economic choices we must make, you will allow me to insist on a remark of a more political nature within the framework of this debate.
Over the past few weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-talk of certain major European leaders or those who think they are.
While everyone keeps calling for a coordination of economic, budgetary and fiscal policies that is finally worthy of the name, and this requirement even appears as a sine qua non condition,
Once they are well settled in, it is Mr. Cro-Malin who criticizes the balanced recommendations from the Eurozone.
the Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst case, to turn public opinion against these "decrees from Brussels", as they are called.
This irresponsible attitude could be laughable if we were not in such a tragic situation.
I'll tell you straight out, our debates on stability, the necessary cleanup of public finances, or the efforts to be made in terms of growth are indeed doomed to failure.
It will fail if the mistakes of the past in terms of debt and public deficit are not ended and if the governments of the Member States continue in their misadventures.
We are playing with fire at this moment.
European discipline must apply to everyone, without exception, even to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
This requires a minimum of courage and our public opinions are ready, much more than some of their leaders want to believe.
And a last word to Mrs. Goulard, otherwise I must show her the blue card. I would say, to finish, to Mrs. Goulard, in redemption, there is purchase.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would first like to commend the determination of the European Commission, and particularly yours, Mr. Commissioner, for having tirelessly placed the relaunch and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

As you mentioned, Commissioner, it has been more than two years since both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the challenges and sectors for which more internal market is needed. More internal market for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also ended up, albeit later, by indicating the importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the 12 priority proposals for the internal market, the 12 levers for growth.
Rather than constantly trying to invent new growth instruments, we have every interest in working with the toolbox we already have.

We are therefore taking the opportunity of the resolution that will be put to a vote tomorrow by our Assembly to send a strong political message to the Member States: more speed and efficiency in the transposition of already adopted directives.
More mobilization and commitment in the newly opened projects. I will only mention one, that of strengthening the mobility of workers, more ease of circulation, more fluidity of circulation.
We will be very interested, Mr. Commissioner, in the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will show both political will and the ability to put pressure on the Member States. Thank you.
We have experienced the Mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the scandal of breast implants, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Mr. Commissioner, the dysfunctions of European health security.
This breast implant scandal, these 14 years of fraud, from 1996 to 2010, unpunished.
There are 500,000 prostheses worn worldwide, 8,000 implant removals, 48,000 confirmed cases of cancer.
Finally, 3,500 complaints were filed. These figures are frightening, shocking.

How, despite the warnings from the American drug agency, the FDA, Mr. Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and convictions for ruptures of prostheses filed in Great Britain, in France in particular, how could the national and European agencies have overlooked such a scam?
This tragedy immediately led us to consider improving the European system for controlling medical devices, as you have just explained.
We must, Mr. Commissioner, today build a new system capable of avoiding scandal. But it is a new system that we must build.
It is announced for the fall, you indicated it, this new legislation.
As co-author of this resolution, I am obviously satisfied.
But, Mr. Commissioner, you seem to want to take into account a large part of our concerns as set out in this resolution.
So, why make an exception that is unacceptable to many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why not want the creation of a market authorization for class 3 medical devices, the most at risk?
Mr. Commissioner Dali, can you explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with an increase in production of more than 2.5%. At the same time, industrialists are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England and in all European countries, prices are falling.
This means very clearly that prices are linked to production volumes and that we must organize production volumes and prices at the same time.
At the same time, today, producers are victims of an increase of more than 44% in vegetable proteins and 30% in the price of cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the need here to ensure that the added value is shared among producers and that farmers are not victims of companies and large-scale distribution.

So I ask the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the challenge of controlling production, but at the same time I say very clearly that the Member States must clean up their own house, because there are countries that have respected the quota rules and others that have not.
And that is also what led to these quotas being called into question.
So there is a double responsibility, the Commission and the Member States.
Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, a single European railway area, that is a beautiful European integration policy.
Here is a fine policy where European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of European women and men.

Too often criticized for its failures, Europe, through this directive, finally shows the way to a major policy of sustainable transport and opens the way to a major policy of railway investment for employment.

I am pleased with the main measures taken in the organization of the railway network, the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, the creation of a five-year multi-annual investment contract, thus stipulating the financing commitments of the...

rail infrastructure, but also I rejoice in the implementation of a transparency of financial flows between managers and operators within the framework of integrated companies. The reminder of non-discriminatory access to certain

... service. And finally, I am pleased with the confirmation sought by the European parliamentarians of certain guarantees, in particular on the social level. For example, the absence of a reference to the minimum service, as well as the total separation between the SNCF and the operator.

But allow me to mention a requirement: that we stop considering, notably on the part of the European Commission, the liberalization of the railway sector as the sole strategic horizon for the development of a single railway area. That we thus decide on a European strategy of integrated investment favorable to employment in Europe.
Also, I would like to ask you a question, Mr. Commissioner Callas, to conclude.
Three days after the European Council of June 28 and 29, after the validation of a growth pact of 120 billion euros to relaunch the European economy,
In particular, by investing in infrastructure. Can you tell us, Mr. Commissioner, what amount the European railway sector is likely to benefit from in the context of this growth package?
Madam President, we will have a debate tomorrow on ACTA, but I would like to address a question tonight, certainly peripheral but extremely important to this subject.
These are the statements made by Commissioner Mr. De Gucht at the International Trade Committee on Wednesday, June 20.
I tell you, if you decide to vote negatively before the European Court rules, let me tell you that the Commission will continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
We have committed to it.
A negative vote will not stop the procedure before the Court of Justice.

Not only do these statements seem to me to be in contradiction with the treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, they bear witness to an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, for democracy in general, and for the citizens that we represent.
At a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President. Well, at this hour, many things have been said.
Mr. Commissioner, I would like to thank you very warmly.
Thanks to your stubbornness, to your procedural tricks, you are allowing us to prove the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Mr. Commissioner, for having pushed hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and 2.8 million to sign petitions.
They have discovered that democracy is played out here, that our European elected officials are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you again to the millions of Internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who are still following us today.
I greet them. They are a breath of fresh air in our institutions, which are too often perceived as technocratic.
Thank you, Mr. Commissioner, but in democracy, there is also another principle.
This is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take our responsibility and I would like to thank you tomorrow for taking yours, your failure, the failure of your working method.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I am speaking on behalf of Maurice Ponga, rapporteur for the Development Commission on the report by Mr. Gallagher.
It seemed important to me to recall that when it wishes to sanction a country that practices unsustainable fishing, it must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of the coherence of policies with development objectives, it is crucial, in my opinion, that the measures adopted in the field of fishing do not call into question the development plans and strategies put in place by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Development Committee by providing that measures should not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when it adopts such measures, to respect the principle of policy coherence with development objectives and that the level of development and the vulnerability of countries be duly taken into account. Thank you.
The third reform of the Common Fisheries Policy must not be made once again against the interests of the fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the poor health of the stocks, as environmental organizations and the European Commission claim, by lumping together all categories of fishing.

It is of course necessary to preserve fish stocks, but it is also necessary to allow our fishermen to live from their activity and preserve the economic fabric, the dynamism and the cultural identity of our coastal regions.
However, the main measures of the European executive are once again aimed at reducing the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than 50% since 1980.

The Commission proposes, among other things, the implementation of transferable individual quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and concentration of the sector, or even the total ban on discharges, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project is probably suitable for the industrial fleet, but in its current state, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would like to congratulate the PPE rapporteur, our colleague Karins, for this difficult report, given the sensitive nature of bilateral negotiations in the energy field between European countries and third countries.
The agreement reached in the trilogue will allow for a quick implementation of the Commission's decision project, and for the sake of pragmatism, we can only be pleased about it.
The Europe of energy is progressing, not fast enough certainly, but it is progressing.
As a major energy importer, the European Union is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to have a more European reflection on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to disseminate more widely to the European Commission information relating to energy agreements while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of a mechanism for informing about intergovernmental agreements will therefore improve transparency in the energy market and thus enable energy supply problems to be anticipated.
I am pleased that the present decision does not create obligations with regard to agreements between commercial companies.
In times of crisis and given the stakes in terms of competition and competitiveness, we had to protect the interests of our companies and the rules of protection of private contracts.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this case.

It was necessary since we started from very far with the basic proposal of the Commission. No specific mention of the outermost regions, directly concerned by the competition of the countries of Latin America, no automatic triggering

No stabilization mechanism, no possibility for our Assembly to request the opening of a safeguard investigation, no consideration of social and environmental standards as a possible unfair competitive advantage.
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote validates the progress made on the International Trade Committee.
Despite everything, this is not enough, because we know that the triggering thresholds of these two regulations are so high that they make these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Moreover, the Commission must provide additional financial support to maintain the competitiveness of the production of community bananas.
Let us remember that many jobs are at stake in these European regions, which already have high unemployment rates.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Charles Goerens for his excellent report.

We all know that the European Union provides more than half of the total global public aid for development. However, as the deadline for the MDGs approaches in 2015, even if some objectives seem to be...
Given the situation, we must ask ourselves how to improve our aid, how to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments, and according to a short- and medium-term schedule.

The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging countries, the land grab, force us to define new priorities. Priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources and access to health care.

Certainly, a European consensus exists, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from decision-making bodies such as the WTO, for example.
Finally and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not only charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
Just look at the markets that are opening up for Europeans in emerging countries, China, Brazil and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better take into account the geostrategic evolution of the last few years, since today's emerging countries were, until recently, developing countries.
Now, as an unavoidable economic power, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline, it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as simple financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join my colleagues from the other groups and those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Thank you, Mr. President. The agenda for change proposed by the Commission raises, in my opinion, many questions, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wishes that, as of 2014, the choice of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of wealth per inhabitant.
As Mrs Ashton reminded us, these issues are not just accounting matters, but deserve a real political debate as regards the definition of our priorities in terms of international cooperation.
Moreover, this differentiated approach is not, in my opinion, in line with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition to more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, let us salute the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall fell.
Despite all this, despite all the progress we have seen since the start of our debate, we must acknowledge that the Single Act is today synonymous with injustice, inequality and economic liberalism.
So I would like to hear from you, Mr. Barnier, Mr. Commissioner, to tell us how we are going to build together a fairer Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.
There are a number of leads and I would like to hear you on these leads which are at the heart of the economic and social crisis as we unfortunately know it: fiscal harmonization, public service
protector, minimum wage in Europe, setting up reinforced cooperation, job-creating, facilitating cross-border cooperation and developing a trade policy.
Here are the issues, I believe, twenty years later, that are before us.
I am counting on you, Mr. Commissioner, so that we can together carry this beautiful policy of European construction.

Thank you, Mr. President. As a member of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Commission, I have closely followed the report of my colleague Regina Bastos on the 20 main concerns of citizens and businesses.
We have discussed this report, which is also linked to our debate on the 20 years of the internal market.
It has been 20 years since the free movement of goods, people, services and capital was supposed to be fully exercised within our living space, exchange, market, internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that at the top of the concerns expressed by our European fellow citizens is the recognition of professional qualifications and that we really need to be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens are waiting for, to be able to implement, in the very near future, procedures for the recognition of their qualifications, their skills, their professional qualifications, that are truly faster, simpler, more effective, less costly.
It is a real challenge.

As a fictitious rapporteur for the EPP group on this subject, the modernization of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to truly meet this major challenge of mobility.
More mobility for more Europe, that is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
Mr. President, this year the Petitions Committee has acquired the right to be automatically associated with the hearing of European Citizens' Initiatives.
This is, for me, the strong signal of the year 2011 for this commission.
Citizens already had a commission to turn to in case of non-compliance with their rights, but this is also now the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I wish that the Petitions Committee could thus be considered more and more often as the privileged interlocutor of citizens in the European Parliament.
This problem of consideration is also found in the results of the positions taken by the Petitions Committee.
Too often, we are approached by citizens who are facing legal entanglements on which we would like to take a position. But while the problems are European, while
Although the solutions should be European, we remain powerless, because subsidiarity is still not combined with European solutions due to a lack of national will.
I will take the difficult example of cross-border divorces. The problems are both national and European when custody or visitation rights cross national borders, in this case Germany's.
Despite the obvious difficulties for many parents to see their children born of a binational union, we remain powerless to act in Parliament.

My proposal that all European citizens have the right to a national mediator, especially from Germany, which sends a lot of petitions, based on the model of the French Ombudsman, has not been followed up.
However, in the case of cross-border divorces, this remains a conciliatory solution that is problematic at the European level and at the national level.
In many cases, European law seems powerless to meet the expectations of citizens.
The European Year of Citizens 2013 will have to deal with the grievances of citizens, the cost of living, but we need the means to act to be...
